story:
The Be Creative Project is an exploration, documentation and celebration of creativity.

Inspired by the belief that creativity is everywhere, we gave 1000 people a blank page with a circle on it and asked them, simply, to 'be creative.' The people who participated spanned all ages, stages, places, and races and the work they produced was equally diverse, resulting in an exciting, varied, and fascinating exploration of the creativity that’s possible not only for artists and creative geniuses, but for everyone.

It's a simple exercise – one person, one sheet, one task– but the results have been delightfully complex. The potential outlets for displaying the sheer depth and variety of the end product have ranged from gallery exhibits, to videos to web experiences. 

Given our limited time and resources, we decided to begin The Be Creative Project with 1000 participants, and producing a video that would explore the nature of creativity and showcase the results we'd received.

With that done, now we want to take it to the next level– to bring the experiment and the results online for anyone to participate and explore– but we can't do it alone.

We’re raising money to bring The Be Creative Project online. Our plan is to launch a web experience that not only allows users to submit their own Be Creative creations, but also to explore other people’s submissions, slicing and dicing the data to compare creativity across ages, locations, genders, dates, concepts, and other various tags.

Depending on the amount of money we raise, we'd also like to develop things like a mobile app, a commenting system, a user community, and even the ability to parse submissions by slightly more complex criteria such as colour or media.

We've been in touch with several freelance web developers in Toronto and are confident we can achieve the web experience we want, but the scale and timing of the website depend on how much money we can raise.

Essential Features:

  • An easy and reliable way to submit creations online
  • Automatically align, scale and colour correct submissions to ensure consistency
  • Allow for manual adjustments before submitting
Extended Features:
  • The ability to explore the database of submissions
  • Sort by age
  • Sort by gender
  • Sort by location
  • Sort by date
  • The ability to compare two segments side by side
Premium Features:
  • Sort by tag
  • Sort by colour
  • Sort by media
  • Integrate music into the web experience
  • Develop a mobile app for submission and exploration
  • Include a robust commenting system
  • Add the ability to create a profile

You should donate to The Be Creative Project because creativity is important and creativity is everywhere.

Because creativity is a truly human quality, and should be celebrated as such.

Because too many people respond to the request to 'be creative' with quiet dismissals of their own creative ability. 

Because too many people were told when they were younger that they aren't creative and for that reason alone have stopped exploring their creativity.

Because too many people think that creativity means just one thing, and just one glimpse at the results of The Be Creative Project can expand that definition.

Because we have the opportunity, not only to see how different kinds of people respond to the request to 'be creative' but to see how people in entirely different years respond to the question. 

Because whatever you donate today will help open eyes, enhance understanding, and democratize creativity.

Emmett Fraser - Director

Emmett is a Toronto-based filmmaker who specializes in the creative combination of live action and animation. He’s the driving force behind The Be Creative Project and is constantly delighted by the results. He ardently believes that everyone can be creative, and loves seeing the endless potential of a blank page with a circle on it.

Justine Feron - Producer

Justine is a brand strategist and graduate of the Yale School of Management. She works in an industry where employees are typically either classified as ‘creative’ or ‘account’ and is interested in breaking down those boundaries by championing the idea that everyone is capable of creativity.

story:
**UPDATE**

Thank you to everyone who has contributed thus far. You are beautiful, brilliant people and we really appreciate your support. You have helped us reach our target and ensure that Forest Fringe will definitely happen this summer. 

However, if we can now raise a little more money in the last couple of weeks of the campaign there are a number of additional things we'll be able to do to make Forest Fringe really, really special this summer. I believe these are what people in the crowdfunding business call Stretch Goals.

£8000  - Forest Fringe Plus! 

This year we're really excited to hopefully be collaborating again with the wonderful people at the Forest Cafe to host a whole mini-programme of shows at Forest Centre +, a massive former job centre in the centre of the city, with work by artists including Verity Standen, Volcano Theatre and Caroline Williams & the Young Vic. Your support will make this new venue happen by helping cover the costs of artist accommodation, production management and some additional technical equipment to ensure this new venue is as well cared for as our other home at the Out of the Blue Drill Hall.

£9000 - Lunch for all Forest Fringe artists

Edinburgh is an incredibly exhausting and expensive place for artists, even those coming to Forest Fringe. Last year we were able to provide every artist at Forest Fringe with a meal on any day they were performing. This made a huge difference, not just to their ability to survive at the festival, but also to sense of community and togetherness we are trying to foster - artists and audiences eating and talking together and generally feeling part of something special. We'd love to be able to do this again. 

£10,000  - Photographer and videographer-in-residence

In 2013 we were able to invite photographer Jemima Yong to come to Forest Fringe as a photographer in residence and she was able to produce this beautiful photo essay documenting everything that happened at Forest Fringe. An additional £1000 would cover travel and accommodation for a photographer-in-residence and a videographer-in-residence, allowing us to document the festival, not only for our benefit and that of the artists, but for all the people who have supported us but aren't able to make it to the festival this summer.


Short Summary

We have been running a free, totally non-commercial venue at the Edinburgh Festival since 2007. 

They say that, in terms of exposure and opportunities, one good run at the Edinburgh Festival is the equivalent of one good year in an artist's career.  Over the years the artists who have worked with us have gone on to win awards, to tour internationally, and to get rave reviews.  Every year we are overwhelmed with applications from artists who have worked with us before, and artists who want to work with us for the first time.  It's clear to us that we're offering something valuable to the careers of the artists we work with.  And over the years those artists have become a community for us.

What makes us different from other Edinburgh venues is that in addition to not charging artists or audience members (like the Free Fringe), we also fund raise to cover all accommodation costs for our artists, so that they can comfortably bring excellent, experimental, non-commercial work to the Edinburgh Festival without worrying about losing money.  

This is year for the third year in a row we'll be working with the brilliant people at Out of the Blue Drill Hall on Dalmeny Street just off Leith Walk to host Forest Fringe in their incredible space. 

The venue is entirely run by volunteers - artists volunteer to run our box office, we volunteer to do the administration and running of the festival, and even our amazing tech team volunteer to run shows. 


What We Need & What You Get

Despite the incredible value of people power, and the generosity of the Out of the Blue drill hall, there are still costs involved in running Forest Fringe.  We need money to rent the space, we need money to print programmes, and we especially need money to rent apartments for artists to stay in during the festival, so that artists aren't funding their own way. 

Forest Fringe is run by three artists - Ira Brand, Andy Field and Deborah Pearson.  We don't get paid for our Edinburgh work - we do it in our spare time, because over the years it's become clear that artists presenting experimental work need us to keep going.  Now we need you to keep going. 

This is the first year that we are no longer eligible for the generous Jerwood Foundation grant that we've received for the last five years.  Because we've chosen to forego the formal administrative structures of becoming a charity, there aren't many foundations or even larger private donors that we are eligible to approach.  This means that this year, if we're going to make our venue happen and support the work of all the amazing artists we've programmed, we really need the community who have worked with us, who have come to see our shows, and who have already contributed with their attention and creativity, to step up and let us know that our Edinburgh venue matters to you. 

Please think of a donation as buying a ticket to this year's festival - or think of it as buying a ticket to last year's festival, or the festival the year before.  If everyone who has ever come to Forest Fringe donates £20 now, we will easily meet our target.

    Any money you donate will go directly to either

    a) The accommodation costs of our artists.  We put up around 20 to 25 artists every festival in shared accommodation.  This usually costs between around £6,000 and £8,000 at minimum.

    b) Technical equipment and support.  This means our lighting rig, and rental of our sound system. This usually costs around £2,000 at minimum.

    c)  The Accessibility Programme.  For the last two years, Forest Fringe has been running an "Accessibility Day" for hearing impaired audiences.  We've built a strong relationship with hearing impaired communities in Edinburgh and we would love to keep this going. This costs around £1,500 at minimum.

    d) Printing our Programme.  This is so that you have a document letting you know what shows are on when.  This costs around £2,000 at minimum.

    In addition to crowdfunding, we're also going to be running a fundraiser, and an online auction.  So there are plenty of different ways to give.  That said, because we do all of this in our spare time, the more money we can raise through this crowdfunding campaign, the more time we have to focus on organizing our Edinburgh events and supporting our Edinburgh artists, as opposed to organizing fundraising events.  So if by some wonderful and beautiful turn of events, we've already hit our £7,000 target for this crowdfunding campaign, we would really appreciate any further contributions you can give through this page.  We need to raise £15,000 total in a few short months, so the more people know about our campaign and give to it, the better.


The Impact

Rather than funding one show or one Edinburgh run, if this crowdfunding campaign is successful, it's going to enable at least 25 experimental artists to come to Edinburgh this year.  It will allow us to keep a venue that's dedicated to experimental work going at an incredibly commercial festival.  If you've come to Forest Fringe in Edinburgh before, please consider donating to ensure that you can come to Forest Fringe in Edinburgh again.

story:
AAC has a studio that provides art for the community in a unique and new way.  We turned restaurant salad bars into art bars for all you can make art experience.  We believe children should be given unlimited supplies, support and space to create...not direction, rules and instruction.  We want each child to express their own individual ideas of art and creation.  AAC provides 1 low rate, requires no parent clean up and does not have time or supply limits.  We believe this makes art inviting, accessible and affordable for all families.  We took it a step further by providing a discount for families that qualify for public assistance.


In addition to our studio, we have a small mobile unit.  Right now due to transport, supply and budget issues, we can only attend smaller schools and events.  


OUR PROJECT:  We want to fully stock a mobile vehicle that can travel to schools and larger areas.  We also want to have it ready to go to show up at parks in low income neighborhoods for random "pop up" art studios next spring/summer.  If we can get a mobile unit vehicle we will sell sponsor space on the side which will pay for the supplies, gas and labor that goes into showing up at these events.  We can also afford to cut the price in half for places that book us.  This will continue our mission to make art accessible to anyone.  With sponsors help and this awesome grant we can afford to take the mobile unit to places like Rockwood community center in Gresham, an area of town that NEEDS art/creativity and something for kids to do.   We can also visit "head start" facilities, homeless shelters and other places to visit families that cannot get to our studio.


WE NEED:

*Ford Transit with AAC Vehicle Wrap 

*To produce/print sponsorship packets that will be what funds this ongoing project.

* 2 additional salad bar set ups

*Storage units/drawers for supplies, tools and paper

* Roll out tables 

*Tools for vehicle: scissors, hot glue guns, aprons/shirts for staff, 

*Initial stock of supplies for mobile events: hot glue, stickers, paint, paper, small trinkets, beads, etc.

WE WOULD LOVE:

*To Secure Funds for 2014 to do free mobile events for our top 10 PDX Non Profits.


THANK YOU!!

<3 <3 <3

From owners Aria and Keno Leighty (and littles Keilani and Jaiden)

Awesome team Members Qianjin Montoya, Daizee Torres, Kirsten Elizabeth

Volunteers Colleen Cubbin, Danae Williams, TJ Rucker, Traci Boettcher

story:
Beatrice Brown will perform an original performance specially created for a one-day exhibition held at Flowers Gallery on Monday 23rd June 2014.

The Gallery space will be radically transformed in order to immerse the audience in the artist’s ritual experience, which involves two performers in a tin bath and several large-scale video projections. Colourful pigments and water constantly falling will plant the atmosphere of this artwork, which aims to explore the themes of baptism, torture, hypnosis, and the hooking of souls from one world to the next.

Beatrice Brown is a complete artist whose practice covers the fields of painting, drawing, performance and music. She has shown her work at the ICA, the Roundhouse, 1 Exhibition Road, Pure Evil Gallery, The Cornwall Biennale and Millenium St Ives. She collaborated with Steve Stella New (Rich Kids, PIL, Iggy Pop, Pearl Harbour) for twelve years on their band Beastellabeast. She has co-written and performed with legendary post punk band Selfish Cunt, on their song titled ‘Whip goes the Crack’ and is currently collaborating with Deadcuts on a new album, ‘Dark is The Night’ (due for release 4th July). She has also recently recorded two tracks for the Jeffrey Lee Pierce project (Iggy Pop, Nick Cave, Deborah Harry).  This year she is working on a dance music project, Fellow Humans.

http://vimeo.com/channels/beatricebrown

Your valuable contribution will help to cover the production costs of this unique performance and video installation. Beatrice hopes to work alongside Director of Photography, Gabi Norland, using a RedEpic camera to create the video works. You can see Gabis' impressive showreel here;

http://gabinorland.co.uk/

As a thank you, you will receive some of Beatrices creations, from a CD by Beastellabeast to a signed print.

In any case, you are welcome to attend the event!*

(Free admission – Flowers Gallery W1S 3LZ - From 11am to 7pm)

*Please note that this event can only be created if we reach our goal only. If the goal is not reached, the raised funds will be used by Beatrice to present her drawings and paintings. Same opening times, same location.

story:
Who we are:

Ash Street Studios is a studio community located in the Hampden neighborhood of Baltimore, MD, and is home to thirteen artists-in-residence. Created for the purpose of supporting emerging artists during the first difficult years of an artistic practice, the space offers semi-private inexpensive studios with access to a community library, wood shop, and a common room with lounge space and a piano.

Ash Street Studios was started in 2013 by a group of enterprising emerging artists looking to further an artistic community after undergraduate art college. Taking over an old auto repair shop, they transformed it; building fourteen studios within the space, a wood shop, and a common space with a communal library. Within Ash Street Studios there are painters, printmakers, sculptors, illustrators, woodworkers, filmmakers, photographers, and emerging visual artists of many mediums and practices.

Founders Jonathan Levy and Corynne Ostermann discovered, upon graduation that there were few studio spaces and communities dedicated to emerging artists in Baltimore, MD. Emerging artists, they noted, diminished in their work capacity and eventually quit their studio practices after art school mostly due to a lack of regular artistic studio community, as well as financial, time, and space constraints. This desire for community and conversation through visual arts is what propelled them to assemble a group of young artists and to open Ash Street Studios.

The goal at Ash Street Studios is to foster a dialogue around all artist-in-residence’s studios and work, the Baltimore artistic community at large, and to keep studio rent as low as possible as to allow emerging artists access to the space.  

Our current artist-in-residence are:

Louis Abene-Meagley http://www.louisabbenemeagley.com/

Josiah Bolth 

June Culp http://juneculp.com/

Marco Dimbo

Nick Jankowski http://robodinoisland.tumblr.com/

Patrick Kelly http://pktoons.deviantart.com/

Chris Koch

Jonathan Levy http://jonathanalevy.weebly.com/

Elizabeth Lilly http://elizabeth-lilly.com

Corynne Ostermann http://www.corynneostermann.com

Sarah Robbins http://www.boneblackpress.com/

Andrew Thorp http://www.andrew-thorp.com/

Liza White 

What we are asking for:

We are asking for a total of $5000. As Ash Street Studios aims to keep studios affordable for all artists within the community, there is often little extra money available to tackle projects within the space that benefit the community and the building it is located in. The first winter at Ash Street was spent without heating, causing many artists to forgo working in their studios during the colder months.

We are raising money to get:

Four Mr. Heater Big Maxx natural gas garage-ceiling heaters installed to evenly distribute heat throughout the building. The quote for the heaters and the installation is $3000.

Our largest garage door repaired so that artists can move sculptures, paintings, tools, and supplies through a working garage door. The quote for the garage door repair is $1500.

A commercial dumpster service started so that artists can dispose of their extra materials, wood pieces, and general studio trash instantly, instead of waiting for trash-run days where items are driven to the city dump. The price of a dumpster service can range anywhere from $200-$500 with initial start-up fees.

Any little amount that you can give to help us reach our goals helps tremendously. Your generosity can be the difference between a cold, unbearable winter to a warm, comfortable, and productive winter for a group of emerging artists trying to build themselves into stable practicing artists within the art world. 

What you will receive:

In return for your contribution, we are offering a variety of perks that range from original artworks, prints in a limited series, handmade books, to experiential and customized items from Bone Black Press and our artists-in-residence.

We are offering—

$1—a major thank you from all the artists-in-residence

$5—1 original drawing on paper from any of our thirteen artists-in-residence

$10—1 linoleum print from our artists-in-residence print collection (choose from 1, 2, or 3)


$15—1 original drawing on paper and 1 linoprint from our artists-in-residence collection (choose from 1, 2, 3)

$25—1 hand-screen printed studio poster, 1 original drawing on paper, and 1 linoprint from our collection (choose from 1, 2, 3)

$50—1 original drawing on paper, 1 linoleum print (choose from 1, 2, 3), 1 hand-screen printed studio poster, and 1 handmade sketchbook (choose on white with pamphlet stitch or brown paper with japanese binding)

           (Pamphlet stitched letter pressed sketchbook)

                   

     (Japanese style binding letter pressed sketchbook)


$75—1 complete set of artist-in-residence linoleum prints, 1 original drawing, 1 hand-screen printed studio poster, and 1 handmade sketchbook (choose from white or brown paper)

$100—1 original painting on paper from any of our artists-in-residence, 1 original drawing, 1 complete set of artist-in-residence linoleum prints, and 1 hand-screen printed studio poster

$100—1 medium canvas, panel, or framed drawing from our list of preselected artists (list below). You select the artist!


$300—1 printing lesson with Sarah Robbins of Bone Black Press at her studio location within Ash Street Studios, Baltimore, MD. Donation includes studio time and materials only

$300—hand-made portrait on canvas, panel, or framed drawing from our list of preselected artists (list below). If within the mid-Atlantic area, this can mean a painting from life as organized between the artist and yourself, if not, a high-resolution image of the person to be painted must be provided. You select the artist!

$500—Personalized stationary made especially for you by Sarah Robbins of Bone Black Press. This can include one run of such items as a letterhead, thank-you notes, or wedding invitations, among other things. Please discuss with Sarah your specifications and design ideas if ordering this perk

$1000—Everything listed above, 1 original drawing on paper, 1 complete print edition, 1 hand-screen printed studio poster, 1 handmade sketchbook, 1 small painting on paper, 1 medium canvas, panel, or framed drawing, 1 printing lesson, 1 portrait, 1 personal stationary, and all of our love

Artists for the special selected perks are:

Corynne Ostermann http://www.corynneostermann.com

Jonathan Levy http://jonathanalevy.weebly.com/

June Culp http://juneculp.com/

Andrew Thorp http://www.andrew-thorp.com/

Louis Abene-Meagley http://www.louisabbenemeagley.com/

Josiah Bolth 

Chris Koch

Delivery of these perks will be within a six-month period of time.


What you should know:

Your donation will help strengthen an artistic community focused on maintaining low rent for all artists within the space and within the Baltimore community. With these donations, we aim to fortify the building and create a stable group that will be able to open its doors with pride to the Baltimore community on a more regular basis. We aim to have Ash Street studios exist for years to come to aid each generation of emerging artist, and with your help, we will be able to. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can't contribute to our campaign, please spread the word on your various social media accounts in order to help us raise our final goal!

http://www.ashstreetstudios.com/

https://www.facebook.com/ashstreetstudiogroupLLC

Thank you for your time and support of Ash Street Studios!
story_txt:
Who we are:
Ash Street Studios is a studio community located in the
Hampden neighborhood of Baltimore, MD, and is home to thirteen
artists-in-residence. Created for the purpose of supporting emerging artists
during the first difficult years of an artistic practice, the space offers
semi-private inexpensive studios with access to a community library, wood shop,
and a common room with lounge space and a piano.


Ash
Street Studios was started in 2013 by a group of enterprising emerging artists
looking to further an artistic community after undergraduate art college.
Taking over an old auto repair shop, they transformed it; building fourteen
studios within the space, a wood shop, and a common space with a communal
library. Within Ash Street Studios there are painters, printmakers, sculptors, illustrators,
woodworkers, filmmakers, photographers, and emerging visual artists of many
mediums and practices.



Founders Jonathan Levy and Corynne Ostermann discovered, upon
graduation that there were few studio spaces and communities dedicated to
emerging artists in Baltimore, MD. Emerging artists, they noted, diminished in
their work capacity and eventually quit their studio practices after art school
mostly due to a lack of regular artistic studio community, as well as financial,
time, and space constraints. This desire for community and conversation
through visual arts is what propelled them to assemble a group of young
artists and to open Ash Street Studios.


The goal at Ash Street Studios is to foster a dialogue around all
artist-in-residence’s studios and work, the Baltimore artistic community at
large, and to keep studio rent as low as possible as to allow emerging artists
access to the space.  
Our current artist-in-residence are:
Louis Abene-Meagley http://www.louisabbenemeagley.com/
Josiah Bolth 
June Culp http://juneculp.com/
Marco Dimbo
Nick Jankowski http://robodinoisland.tumblr.com/

Chris Koch
Jonathan Levy http://jonathanalevy.weebly.com/
Elizabeth Lilly http://elizabeth-lilly.com
Corynne Ostermann http://www.corynneostermann.com
Sarah Robbins http://www.boneblackpress.com/
Andrew Thorp http://www.andrew-thorp.com/
Liza White 
   

What we are asking
for:
We are asking for a total of $5000. As Ash Street Studios
aims to keep studios affordable for all artists within the community, there is
often little extra money available to tackle projects within the space that
benefit the community and the building it is located in. The first winter at
Ash Street was spent without heating, causing many artists to forgo working in
their studios during the colder months.
We are raising money to get:
Four Mr. Heater Big
Maxx natural gas garage-ceiling heaters installed to evenly distribute heat
throughout the building. The quote for the heaters and the installation is $3000.
Our largest garage
door repaired so that artists can move sculptures, paintings, tools, and
supplies through a working garage door. The quote for the garage door repair is
$1500.
A commercial dumpster

pieces, and general studio trash instantly, instead of waiting for trash-run
days where items are driven to the city dump. The price of a dumpster service
can range anywhere from $200-$500
with initial start-up fees. 
Any little amount that you
can give to help us reach our goals helps tremendously. Your generosity can be

story:
Kalamazoo!

We need an all-ages community art space!

Though our city’s arts culture is bursting at the seams, we have no artspace in the city that is inclusive to everyone. Our town proudly and strongly supports fine art, but many other focuses are just as active with no space to call home. We've had to find unconventional spaces to host events that would otherwise not happen... and these spaces are not always accessible to all. A community art space with specific focus on diversity, all-ages events, drug and alcohol free policies, and safe space ethics would foster a positive impact on our community as a whole. Thus, we propose: The KCAC, or Kalamazoo Collective Arts Center.




The KCAC would be an all-encompassing open space for people to gather, learn, create, and experience regardless of age, income, and ability.

As previously mentioned, the KCAC will hold steadfast to these focuses:

Diversity
Our city is alive with so many sounds and sights! We would like as many as possible to be represented at the KCAC. Bringing the community together is one of our top priorities and we can't do it by sticking to just a couple walks of life.

All-Ages
A topic near and dear to our entire board. All-ages spaces are essential to the positive growth and impact on our area's youth. Though our city does have an active house show and bar show scene, our young are left out almost entirely. Both houses and bars are cliquish by their nature and many are turned away because of age. We believe this space should be accessible to all, in terms of, "whoever wants to go, can show up."

Drug and Alcohol Free
Though Kalamazoo boasts an awesome amount of regionally- and nationally-renowned breweries that happen to be a hub of where social interaction peaks and where art is frequently paired with alcohol, by law they are exclusive to the drinking-age crowd and are not inclusive to people in recovery, straight edge communities, and people who don't wish to be around alcohol to enjoy a show.

Safe Space
As defined by Advocates for Youth, a space space is, "A place where anyone can relax and be fully self-expressed, without fear of being made to feel uncomfortable, unwelcome, or unsafe on account of biological sex, race/ethnicity, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, cultural background, age, or physical or mental ability; a place where the rules guard each person's self-respect and dignity and strongly encourage everyone to respect others." Our board strongly believes in these viewpoints and will uphold them to the best of our capacity.


Drawing influence from art spaces across the country, but most specifically: The DAAC in Grand Rapids, we want this space to be as user-run as possible and to host any events like shows, workshops, art showings, lectures and open discussions, live performances, film showings, etc. 

With a board comprised of long-time active community members passionate about our causes, the KCAC intends to apply for non-profit status and to secure a location by the end of this year. We intend to sustain the space by grant funding and community donations. Further down the road, we hope to expand the KCAC to include studios, a lounge, and an array of tools and resources for the community to use, such as a darkroom, screen printing shop, a digital media lab.

With your help, we can make this dream a reality!



Your donations will go towards:

  • Mostly to leasing or buying a space. A space for us all!
  • After that's taken care of, we'll put money towards licenses, registrations, permits, insurance, and inspection fees.
  • If the building requires work, we’ll be reconstructing damaged walls, fixing plumbing and electrical work, and whatever else the space needs!

Having this space matters to us because it shows our community that anyone can be involved and anyone can make a difference. Anyone can book a show, book a band, book an art show, and it should be accessible to all. For all of the support we have already received from the community, we are so grateful and we'll continue to work towards having this positive space to share.

Do it Together, Kalamazoo!







Video filmed & Edited by Zac Clark 
Extra footage shot by Jessica Walters
Selected footage from the film "Weird People Do Good Things"

Song : "Gwenz" by Boring People

The KCAC is:Kasey Chaos, Russ Wagner, Rory Svekric, Chafe Hensley,
Steve Walsh, Bridget Dooley, Ike Turner, John Wagner.
More about us here: the KCAC | kalamazoo collective arts center

story:
Goals of REMAINDERS…
• Educate participants of all ages in the art of creative reuse and benefit the greater community through art and maker activities.
• Collect and redistribute donated materials to a wide variety of programs, organizations, teachers, artists, parents, and students in the community.
• Divert tons of quality reusable materials from landfills.

At REMAINDERS Creative Reuse Materials Depot and Learning Center, creativity is a way of life. There are limitless resources, and the programs and workshops which artists and volunteers, have designed for REMAINDERS, teach strong creative skills, self-esteem and promote a sense of individuality through creative activities. The activities at REMAINDERS give the gift of self expression, and set the stage for the future of our community, society and humanity, because the very process of creating promotes the development of creative intelligence.

REMAINDERS is modeled after SCRAP in San Francisco, which has been running successfully since 1976 (www.scrap-sf.org). They have generously encouraged this endeavor.

The funding from this campaign is Seed Money to open the materials depot in Pasadena. With this financial foundation, REMAINDERS will be self-supporting shortly after it opens its doors. The 5000 square foot space where everything is housed, is donated. 

$2000 for Start Up Fees (incorporation, 501c3 application, state fees, legal) $2000 for Marketing (printing, mailing, advertising, etc.)                               $2000 for Transportation (vehicle expenses, gas, etc.)                                   $2000 for Infrastructure (equipment, shelving, building materials, etc.)     $2000 for Other (insurance, paid labor for set up - staff is volunteer)

All perks are flexible, transferable, and will never expire.

Even if we do not reach the monetary goal of this campaign, this organization will be a GO. The donations will just determine how quickly. REMAINDERS' commitment to the Pasadena area and the Greater Los Angeles community is solid.

If you are unable to give at this time, please help us give the gift of creativity to this community while raising environmental awareness, and share this campaign with others. Also, we can always use volunteers - particularly in legal, accounting, procurement, and administration. Indiegogo tools are useful too.

Feel free to contact us directly at remainderspas@gmail.com or www.facebook.com/remainderspas

story:
AnnVanART - annvanart.weebly.com

Am Anfang war diese Idee:
Wieso nicht einfach so dreist sein und Künstler werden?
Bilder machen und berühmt werden? Das wupp´ ich! Wenn nicht jetzt, wann dann?
Aus einer sehr flatterhaften und unüberlegten Spinnerei wurde jedoch sehr schnell Ernst und nun stehe ich vor der ersten Ausstellung, wer hätte es gedacht.
Im Dezember darf ich zusammen mit 5 anderen Künstler - richtigen Künstlern, die das studiert haben und alles - 7 Bilder präsentieren.

Nachdem die erste Euphorie verflogen ist, kommt jedoch langsam die Verwirklichung des Ganzen.
Blöde nur, wenn man keine Kohlen für die Finanzierung der Bilder hat.

Alle "Kunstwerke" existieren bis jetzt nämlich nur in digitaler Form.
Die Fotografien, die ich mit Bildbearbeitungsprogrammen verändert habe, müssen schließlich ausgedruckt werden.
Ich produziere jedoch keine Klein- sondern Großformate - das heisst, meine Bilder sind mindesten einen Meter breit - wegen dem Effekt versteht sich - wäre ja langweilig!
Natürlich geht das ins Geld, welches ich nicht habe!
Und bevor ich diese Chance einfach verstreichen lasse oder nur halbherzig angehe, wende ich mich an Euch mit der Bitte, mir ein wenig unter die Arme zu greifen!



Für die Ausstellung dachte ich an 700 Euro.

Etwa 600 gehen an die Druckerei.
Die soll die Bilder natürlich mit der bestmöglichen Qualität drucken.
Bei einer Größe von etwa min. 100x50 cm wären wir schon bei min. 50 Euro, dann ist noch kein Rahmen dabei und die finale Größe ist eh noch nicht erreicht.
Ich denke, Ihr versteht was ich meine.
Es soll eben wirklich nach was ausschaun! Sonst hat das alles schließlich keinen Zweck!
Den Rest wende ich für Geschenke auf....also Dankeschöns.
Ganz so leicht kommt Ihr mir nicht davon!

Dass ich mit der ganzen Idee, Künstlerin zu werden, nicht ganz auf dem Holzweg bin, beweist Interessenbekundung für eine weitere Ausstellung - dazu verrate ich aber noch nichts.

Aus Jux und Tollerei ist schnell etwas greifbares geworden und ich würde diesem Wahnsinn gerne nachgehen, wenn ich darf.
Wenn da wirklich eine kleine Tür aufgehen sollte, dann würde ich gerne durchgehen!
Schaut Euch gerne auf meiner Homepage   www.annvanart.weebly.com   um!
Anfänglich habe ich Müll fotografiert, mittlerweile sind es absurderweise Blumen gewesen, mit denen ich gearbeitet habe und jetzt suche ich mir was Neues!

Ich langweile mich schnell, ich hoffe aber, Ihr tut das nicht!

Ich bedanke mich schon jetzt für alles was kommt!

 Schaut Euch gerne auf meiner Homepage   www.annvanart.weebly.com   um!Anfänglich habe ich Müll fotografiert, mittlerweile sind es absurderweise Blumen gewesen, mit denen ich gearbeitet habe und jetzt suche ich mir was Neues!Ich langweile mich schnell, ich hoffe aber, Ihr tut das nicht!Ich bedanke mich schon jetzt für alles was kommt!

story:
Glasgow Open House Art Festival

About Us

Glasgow Open House Art Festival will run for ten days from April 11th - 21st 2014. Our programme of visual arts, performance and music includes the work of over 80 artists scattered across 32 venues in every corner of Glasgow.

This year’s programme includes exhibitions and events in flats, gardens, sheds and other unexpected locations, reflecting the work of individual artists, collaborative groups and organisations. We aim to offer an alternative format for public interaction with art outside of the gallery, generating discussion around the way art is exhibited and consumed both in and out of doors.

We are an artist-led, non-profit voluntary organisation that exists to support and maintain autonomous artistic activity in the city.

We hope that the festival will become an annual event providing a platform for artists in the city year-upon-year.

As part of the lineage of DIY culture in Glasgow, Open House makes use of the space easily available to the artist – the artists’ home and outdoor spaces. The festival organisers are keen to engage with new audiences by opening up their living and working environments to neighbours, fellow artists and the public. The organisers aspire to engender critical discussion around the way art is exhibited and consumed.

Why we need your support 

With your help we hope to make Glasgow Open House Art Festival an annual platform for artists in the city!

We have already received funding from The Hope Scott Trust and our fund-raiser event in January but we hope to get some extra support through our Crowdfunding film to make this possible. 

As we progress as an organisation we hope to have the means to support our artists and participants financially by way of bursaries and commissions.

Any support is appreciated so please follow us on Twitter and Facebook and invite all of your friends to celebrate the opening year of Glasgow Open House Art Festival!

Tweet us at:@OHglasgow

Follow us on: facebook.com/glasgowopenhouse

Visit us at: http://glasgowopenhouse.co.uk/

story:
Short Summary

Rate My Artist Residency was founded January 2013 in Berlin, Germany by Katrina Neumann (a visual artist). Rate My Artist Residency acts in part as a public relations platform for emerging and established residencies, alternative programming, and artistic communities. The website promotes professional practices, links to other residency resources, a peer review pen pal, and a calendar of upcoming events. The main impetus for beginning Rate My Artist Residency was to create clarity behind residency programs and allow artists to have a social platform to engage anonymously and exchange information about their experiences.

The Artists Helping Artists Grant is an idea launched from Rate My Artist Residency’s subtitle. One of the most difficult obstacles with artist residencies is being able to afford the residency. I want to utilize crowd-sourcing fundraising on indiegogo to create a grant that need-based artists in the United States can apply to unrestricted funding for a residency in 2015. The artists’ who apply to the grant must provide proof of need-based income and a letter from the residency with their acceptance in 2015. A jury will review finalists and select the recipients of the Artists Helping Artists Grant. The application for the grant will launch in Fall 2014 and the award will be announced in the new year of 2015.

The raised funds through this new initiative will be split into four portions and awarded to the selected artists. Currently, the fundraising goal is $2,000 USD and each artist will receive around $500 USD for the residency (indiegogo fees apply). The grant is unrestricted and used towards the residency as the artist sees fit; this includes residency fees, artist materials, studio space, travel, room, board, food, shipping, a portion of their apartment rent, etc. It is my hopes to raise more than the $2,000 USD goal to help artists receive a larger stipend this year and years to come.


(Photography (c) 2013 Jonathan Hordle/Rex Features)


What We Need & What You Get

The Artists Helping Artists Grant’s goal is $2,000 USD. All of the funds from the fundraising goal (whether more or less) will be split into four unlimited need-based residency grants. The grant is awarded to four artists that demonstrate a need for financial assistance and have been awarded a residency for the following year. The unrestricted grant allows the artist to attend the residency and be able to pay for residency fees, materials, travel, room, board, shipping of materials, food, etc. The use of the funds are at the discretion of the artist while in residence. Your contributions help other artists carve out the time and space needed to make their work and build their career through the social opportunities provided at artist residencies worldwide.

If you donate between $25-$50, your application fee for the grant is waived. The application fee goes towards the administrative costs with the remaining balance contributing to theArtists Helping Artists Grant. If you donate $50, you and a friend of your choice will have your application fee waived for the residency grant.

Donors that contribute $100-$500 will be listed on the Rate My Artist Residency website as a Friend, Collector, and Benefactor. Collectors and Benefactors of the Artists Helping Artists Grant will receive a limited edition postcard sized work from the selected grant recipient artists. The Collectors receive one work from an artist of their choice and The Benefactors receive four works of limited edition postcard sized works from all of the selected artists (A Suite Collection).

If the Artists Helping Artists Grant does not reach it’s entire goal, then the funds will still be divided by four and given to need-based artists in the United States that receive a residency in 2015. If the funds are below $50, then the donations will be returned.


The Impact

It goes without saying that for many years artists have benefited from residency programs around the world. Each program is an individual gem and at times a utopia for artists to temporarily exist. These programs give artists the vital time and space allowing them to work on their projects, ideas, and creation of contemporary culture. I always considered artist residency programs as an alternative business conference for the art world. Artists attend these spaces as think tanks, social network hubs, and pockets of conversation and dialogue analyzing our current and future position as a society in the world today. Artists are catalysts and act as the epitome representation of freedom in society. By supporting the works of artists, you are supporting progressive thought, change, challenging thought provocation, the right to a free equal society, and an individual working on cultural production.

Rate My Artist Residency was born from the idea of having a social platform for artists to communicate with each other about their residency experiences. The website launched over a year ago and today has over 900 followers. In the past year, over 50,000 visitors from 100 countries visit the website to check out deadlines, residency profiles, and ratings of different residency programs. This is the first trial initiative of the grant through crowd-sourcing tactics; I hope that it finds great success and is able to continue for years to come.

Your contributions create a dynamic shift in grant giving through crowd-sourcing and contributing to the career of a need-based artist. Thank you.


Other Ways You Can Help

Want to help but just don’t have the funds? No worries! You can post this to your social media pages, websites, send emails, and make a fuss about Artists Helping Artists Grant! Just click share, and, BOOM! We are eternally thankful.

story:
Hey folks!

Just found out that I've got a spot at Renegade Craft Fair: SXSW Edition in Austin, Texas. The event is coming up soon -- March 13-15 -- and I need your help to make this a reality.

What's the cash gonna cover?

Transportation and food. I live in Pittsburgh. Austin is 1,418 miles away. I'll need to rent a car and gas it up. And I gotta eat.

  • A rental car - est. $400
  • Gas - est. $400
  • Food - est. $400
I'm staying with friends in Nashville and Austin -- so luckily there's no need to cover hotels. I did bump up the food to included some thank-you meals for my kind hosts.

What this means for me -

The Renegade folks estimate an audience of 90,000 will flow through that weekend. SXSW attracts people from all over and that sort of exposure is something I can't miss. I'll be able to stand by my work and introduce it to an international audience.  

Some of the available perks -

Signed Armadillo to Zebu book is available with a $20 donation

Black & White Hen print is available with a $30 donation.

Nighttime Elephant print is available with a $30 donation.

Party Sloth print is available with a $30 donation.

Squirrel Reading print is available with a $30 donation.


Or choose your own print with a $30 donation from any Hey Beast Studio project - Armadillo to Zebu, 365 Critters, 52 Things, or The Get Downs. Just check out my image archive and see what you like. Contact me at heybeast12@gmail.com if you have any questions.

Other Ways You Can Help -

Cash is tight -- believe me, I know. If you're unable to contribute financially, please feel free to share this link with family and friends.

Thank you

The likes and comments online, the folks who stopped by and bought prints and books at Pittsburgh markets, those of you who have commissioned original pieces, and family and friends who are always willing to help and attend events. All these things add up and that energy and support is why this event in March is happening. Thank you.

story:
Dear indiegogo users.

My name is André Aksetøy, co-creator of bimbear.com, I have a background in architectural technology and construction management. I am currently working at an architectural company based in Trondheim.

Me and my study friend Ivan Dimitrov have almost 10 years of experience in 3D modelling. And we both agree that the current 3D building objects are to big and difficult to work with, and they don't pay tribute to the product designer in the way they look.

our objects, rendered with revit


We have spent most of our personal time working on objects, presentations and website building, the last is something we know close to nothing about. We will have beta launch on the 1st of October, but we would like a professional website builder to help us with the finished product. This is why we are asking for funding. 

If you are a user of building objects in revit you most likely share our frustration about the current building information objects. If you fund us you get beta access where you can download 150 objects that look as good as the picture attached, even more important is how light they are. You won't need a NASA computer to furnish the bedroom. If you fund a bit more you will also get a membership with the finished site where we will add objects at a daily basis.

If you are a designer or manufacturer and fund us, we will create your products in 3D and feature it on our site where it will reach architects all over the world. The objects will of course have description on where the product can be bought and a link back to your website. And the objects will be free to download for the public.

We hope that you will fund us, and if you are in the business we hope that you can spread the good word.

Best regards,

André and Ivan

story:
Short Summary

    THE HIGH GRADE ARTISTRY TOUR aims to share the unique blend of live art, music, fabrication and community building with populations far and wide. The tour will focus on promoting and introducing the best of what Downtown Trenton has to offer!  

    By building, creating and experimenting with locally available resources and community partners, our artists aim to share their skills and jumpstart grassroots activism in new locations

    Using urban infused artistry and techniques honed during completing large scale projects pulled off with civic involvement, the HGA Tour will be an unprecedented achievement in showcasing Trenton, NJ rapidly growing Arts scene while promoting the state capital in a positive light. 

    The purpose of this tour is to bring new art and culture to the Trenton area by traveling outside our little "bubble," showcasing our talent regionally, and connecting with artists in other areas of the country. Just as local art scenes within Trenton have been connecting and cross-pollinating lately, we believe it's time to connect with other like-minded artist groups in areas outside our city. With these connections made, we can invite artists back to Trenton in the coming years to help diversify our local art scene. This tour will not only help put Trenton on the map as an urban arts hub, but also build bridges for artists and performers to travel to and from our city.
THINGS WE NEED!
We Need to get a BUS first! $5000

Then we need to get the materials and paint to modify the BUS. $1000

(Not exactly this but you get our point)
Live Painting $1000 : Aerosol Paint Budget (200 cans and acrylics=1,000) .this will be enough paint for the entire 4 month tour

Live Wielding and Bike Demo: $1000
Tall bike and welding workshop budget

Pendulum Painting:Paint budget  $1000



Video and film for Tour:  $2000
Food and Gas
$4,000
               


Total budget for tour: $15,000

WHAT WE DO:
Before: 

After:

Before:

After:


Before:



After:

story:
I am not a skilled person. I know a lot about pro wrestling, and I am a fan of math and astronomy, but that is about it. I get bored at most "real" jobs fairly quick and usually end up quitting within a few months. The only real constant in the last decade has been pro wrestling, and a few people tell me that I am pretty good at certain parts of it. Unfortunately, my total lack of focus has left me unable to afford anything to make me look like anything more than a sack of shit when I am wrestling. 

I would love for you to give me some money. I need knee pads, boots and tights. A video camera and some production equiptment would help me to get some weird wrestling shit out there too.  I am trying not be a complete charity case, so hopefully the perks I am offering make some sort of sense.

My video pitch is just a sample of my wrestling "ability". Give me some money and I will be sure to get weirder with it then I ever thought possible.

story:
Short Summary

Apparently, contributors only fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some reasons to like and trust me.

  • I'm ballsy enough to drive a glorified golf cart 1200 miles.
  • You can trust me, I'm a lawyer. But actually.
  • This is trip is a blessed and magical journey of Biblical proportions. Your support means so much to me beyond covering gas & website costs.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • After Indie Gogo takes their cut, I'll need about $3k-3500 to cover my car repairs and un-hose me from roadtrip expenses
  • I'll need at least $1,000 to hire my Gonzo artist of choice to draw the book cover for Electric Desert Madness
  • The balance will go to digitally publishing, distributing and promoting the book. This will include basic overhead for my website, advertising and a limited run of paperback copies.

The Impact

If you watch my video, I talk about donating the proceeds from my book sales to fund after school art programs in public schools. I actually haven't chosen which organization I want to donate the proceeds to because I want the money to go to public schools but public school funding is so fucked up and I want to make sure it's really going to get somewhere. I am doing research now and am so open to suggestions. 

  • Here's one I've been seriously looking into http://www.lacerstars.org/ that's based in Los Angeles.
  • But, like I said, I really want there to be real impact so if anyone is personally involved or know someone who's involved in a US based program like this, please hit me up on Twitter @youfoundmolly55

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have any cash to spare? Or maybe you're just not sure about me. That's ok, you can help in other ways!

  • Share this campaign anywhere you can!
  • Pick up a Hunter S. Thompson book, letter or short story and read that shit. Hell pick up anything and read it, reading is awesome and you might learn something.
  • Buy my book at ifoundmolly.com when it's released June 23rd!

story:
She is Elle

I am Nani, Elle's mother and one of her many big fans. We live simply in an eco-village. We live simply indeed and work very hard. I did not know that perhaps the greatest gift that I could give Elle would be technology. I've provided fresh air, good food, intellectuals and artists...all in a rural setting. I wanted to give her the best world that I knew to give her. All mothers want this. I was not equipt to provide computers and hardware. Technology is quite obviously a gateway to boundless creative adventures for Elle. Elle has taken to creating on line, exhibiting her humor, dance, music, graphics via a computer for the last few years. I "inherit" computers that would die and recover them...as best I can. Alas, our family has hit a point where my skills are far behind Elle's and I feel her bridled spirit. With your help another child, a native Hawaiian,  who has lived a life underserved will finally have a tool real and significant to boost her contribution to creativity!

Elle needs a high performing computer

$2000 is our goal.

When I've compared the technology I think will serve her the best for years to come it was in the ballpark of $1400-$2000. All monies that she raises and that are raised for her will feed her hungry artistic nature. Firstly, technology and then what ever else she may need: easel, a good camera, field trips to places like City Museum in St.Louis, mixing board, looping pedals, instruments. These are things that we only dream of at this point.

Elle already has excitement about gifting you with drawings, sketchups, character designs, sculptures, products that she creates for you. We also have artist and other contributing friends that will support Elle by gifting you with pottery, jewelry, and original works of art as well.

Every tribute will serve Elle. Should we not meet our goal, every coin still feeds back into her tool kit. If the half way mark, at the least, is met, then Elle will continue her fundraising towards a high quality computer. In the chance that we are less our half way mark, I will allow Elle the option to use her funds for something affordable that will continue to let her grow!

I mentioned she is also working to raise funds.

Another way to help her and her grandma!

Grandma, myself, and Elle came up with an entrepenurial way to symbiotically help Grandma and Elle. You too may assist these ladies (mini lady) and benefit with a fun investment...of a doll.

I imagine that you came to our campaign because you love artist and wanted to support an artist. We gladly accept your contribution and want to give you art. Elle also is able to give you a collectable dolly, courtesy of her very intense doll collecting grandma, at a lower that it's resell value in gratitude, in consideration of your contribution. Symbiosis? Elle collects 30% and %70 goes to grandma. G'ma, not so techy, 10 year old is very confident that she could move Grandma's dollies for her. We recognize the uniqueness of this proposal. It may be your cup o tea or not. If it is, let us know. Elle will be thrilled to be able to give Grandma money and earn some herself.

You never know who wants to help:)

Please tell your friends about us, post, or tweet. Heck, if you feel so inclined tell your local artist or nerd about us or nerdy artist...even better.

You may copy and paste into emails or bb's or forums any part of our campaign or simply use any tools indiegogo has to offer to make us POPULAR!  The more we are viewed and gifted to, Indiegogo will share our story up front and center, then the more likely we will succeed.

Mahalo nui (I thank you greatly),

Nani

Mahalo nui (I thank you greatly),
Nani

story:
Photographer and Artist-Leila May

Artist Statement

My body of work “The Pirate Steals a Bride” is an exploration of relationships through the photographic process. I am recording moments which I recognize within the created environment of book, seeds, plant, soil— the beauty of growth coming through the pages, the beauty in a dying object, decay in life and the new and continuing relationship between two things that become completely connected, yet continually change each other.

I am setting up an implicit and explicit relationship between a book, specifically a romance novel and the seeds that will grow into plants by using the book as nutrients to grow. This relationship has many layers of meanings, at it’s simplest context— one decays and dies, so the other will grow and live. Which also acts as a metaphor for a sexual relationship.

An additional layer of content is the novel itself and the cover art of the embracing couple in the throws of lovemaking. The man is the hero in the novel and the woman needs rescuing is a running theme in the book’s text and on the cover. If the couple will overcome the obstacles in their way, they can be happy and together. A fantasy relationship which never existed and doesn’t in contemporary times, the dying book is a symbol of the death in the belief in a perfect relationship.

 

Why I need your help...

I went back to school to get my MFA in Studio Arts/Photography after being out of school for many years. I decided to go back to school in my 40s, so I could have more career opportunities. I love photography and want to continue my passion by teaching.

I have been working on this project for over a year and it's time to show the work and finish my MFA. Professional mounting and presentation will make this work look the way it should, but costly. I am looking for help to complete the project and in return you will be listed in my catalog of the show and possibly have a beautiful print to hang on your wall. This project may turn into a book, if it does, you will be listed there as well.

Thank you for supporting the arts and any artist who needs a little extra support.

www.leilamayphotography.com

Leila

Art makes the world more beautiful.

story:
Hello! My name is Krys and I am the head maker at Craftystuffs, a blog about making, upcycling and crochet, as well as a craft guild member of Alamance Makers Guild!  This past year, I have needed to take time off due to a number of personal reasons.  Now that I am back on my feet and have a new direction for the site, I am rearing to go!

    I am writing this in hopes that you can help me raise the necessary funding to re-launch my website, including FREE tutorials and be able to host giveaways.  I like making tutorials, both video and pictoral step by steps, from subjects ranging from crochet to making an upcycled display on the cheap!  I am also working on two books: One,about making stuff yourself and making it look GOOD, the other is an alternative crochet book, with tips on carpal wrist relief tips and crochet common sense.

    What I am seeking is only $1500 to help me get neatly squared away to start this endeavor.  A camera capable of macro and short video tutorials,  I am buying used and looking at a reasonable camera that fills these needs, as my digital point and shoot died a horrible death.  Internet hosting for the website/domain, supplies and tools for the tutorials, business cards, supplies for the make-it kits with make-it 'zine to accompany all the materials needed for some great projects, and some outlying costs for bringing the brand to life.  

    I am asking a very modest amount mainly because I have put much of my own time, sweat and money into this and would love to see this bring light to people who never thought they could crochet or make something themselves. 

     I am offering awesome handmade items made by me, your name emblazoned on the site and a thank you card with illustration hand drawn by mois. I thank you all in advance for any contribution you can make.  I am not doing this to be rich, but to share the love of handcrafting... Something I am passionate about sharing!  

   Even if I do not reach My goal of $1500, my priority one is the camera so I can still do the tutorials. This will not change as everything else is just going to enrich the experience and make it possible to get the word out.

  Thank you for reading over the tutorial, This started with an operational cost of $5 a month for crafts, two years ago when a friend told me I had a gift for teaching different learning levels to make beautiful things. I also apologize for the "video", as I have no camera to make something high quality ( yet...)

 Crafts and Smiles, Krys of Craftystuffs

story:
The Lookbook
MJC lookbooks was created as a Facebook Resource and Social Network by Bridgette.

  • Bridgette is not compensated for her time and efforts
  • Expenses for everything including swag, buttons and "Pay It Forward" gifts/shipping come directly out of her pockets.
  • Her efforts have succceeded in bringing together a thriving online community. She is a valuable personal contributer with a track record of heroic and kind efforts in both her local community and in this virtual community.
  • Bridgette is not formerly endoresed or compensated by Matilda Jane Clothing.


Who put this togther?
This campaign was created by an unsolicited group of her friends and mothers (who daily reference her lookbooks pages,) that would like to send Bridgette to Art Fair as a "Thank you" for all of her great efforts.

While Bridgette is aware of this campaign and is thankful for the efforts on her behalf, she has not directly solicited this Pay-It-Forward effort.

Your contributions
Your contributions are greatly appreciated. They will go directly to Bridgette for the purpose of

  1. Funding her Secured Ticket (cost $1,000) to MJC "Behind the Scenes Dinner"
  2. Funding her Secured Ticket (cost $500) to MJC "Chicks for Children Luncheon"


Any funds raised in excess of the goal amount will be kept, in trust, by Bridgette (MJC lookbooks) and be used at her sole discretion. The funds may be used for MJC lookbooks related expenses such as  Pay-It-Forward opportunities, Lookbooks web funding development or realated efforts as Bridgette sees fit.

*Matilda Jane Clothing is in no way a part of, or liable for the activities generated by this campagin or facebook community. This is a mom-for-moms effort, so please be kind in reactions and support.

story:
"With Coal, we have light, strength, power, wealth, and civilization; without Coal, we have darkness, weakness, poverty, and barbarism. The most civilized nations of the world are those consuming the most Coal."

William J Nicolls, The Coal Catechism, 1898

 

We are artists based in Berlin, Germany and Manchester, UK and we are looking for your support in the  production of a new video work. 
 
 
The Project
 
Song for Coal looks at coal as a cypher for the environmental and conceptual impacts of our carbon based economies and is based upon The Coal Catechism, an 1898 publication by William Jasper Nicolls.  The work looks at human induced climate change and explores apocalyptic fears present within our current understanding of the unfolding Century. It deals with the Industrial Revolution not as a distinct event that happened 150 years ago in north-west Europe but rather as an ongoing process that we are still caught up in.
 
By the end of this decade Coal is likely to rival oil as the world's biggest source of energy (see Guardian article).  It is a material which has conditioned the shift from agrarian to urban societies and as a driver of climate change will continue to define transformations in human life into the 21st century.
 
For producing this film we are working with a chorus of Opera singers to record the libretto (who've kindly agreed to donate their time to do so) and the complete work is scheduled for presentation at Yorkshire Sculpture Park in Autumn 2014. 
 
Normally we shoot our films indoors using an HDV camera.  For Song for Coal we will be going on location as well as doing hi-resolution imaging of the coal in motion.  For this we want to use particular equipment and we're hoping you can help us raise £2000 towards costs related to equipment hire.  This is for things like cranes and macro lens hire as well a high end RED camera for shooting details.  Your support will be used to make crucial elements of the work possible.
 
 
 
About us
 
We work collaboratively and our work is primarily concerned with the languages of power, with its grammar and with its rhetoric. Our projects address questions around faith, politics, national identity and the environment.
 
If you're not familar with work we've made in video before please see our vimeo channel or website.  Reviews of our works in recent years have appeared in journals like Art Forum, Art Monthly and Art Review.  Recent exhibitions have been at SALT, Istanbul; Plataforma Revólver, Lisbon; Institute of Jamais Vu, London and Isolation Room, St Louis.  Our current project From An has been commissioned by Film and Video Umbrella, London.  From An is a series of downloadable pdf artworks available from MerzBank.  In autumn 2013 we will be exhibiting at the Northern Gallery of Contemporary Art, Sunderland and are making a new work for The Whitworth Art Gallery, Manchetser.  We will also be doing a residency and exhibition at LoBe, Berlin.
 
To encourage your support we've produced some editioned artworks - please see the right panel - also we've posted some pics in the gallery.  Please support the production of Song for Coal.  With your help we are going to make a beautiful and powerful work.

story:
Short Summary

My goal is to partner with high school and college students to paint murals in different neighborhoods that depict visual narratives about several Hip-Hop artists from Queens, NYC, whose style, lyrics, ambition and creativity influenced a cultual phenomenon worldwide.

Did you know that pioneers such as Nas, Run-DMC, Salt-n-Pepa, LL Cool J, A Tribe Called Quest, Lost Boyz, KRS-1, Ja-Rule, Marley Marl, 50 cent, Nicki Minaj, Roxanne Shante, Lloyd Bank... Russell Simmons ALL are Hip-Hop artists that hail from the borough of Queens in New York City?

Growing up in Saint Albans and knowing that so many people from my neighborhood had risen to success as artists, made me feel like it was possible for me to make my dreams come true too. I think more should know the stories of these Hip-Hop influencers and the community should be a part of sharing the history to the world.

As an artist and a cultural documentarian, I believe it is important to document and preserve our history while it is happening and alive, rather than waiting for someone else to tell it after the fact. I proudly volunteer to take on this role of presenting multiple sides of Hip-Hop through stories of triumph as well as cautionary tales about temptation, and making them accessible for the public and for future generations to learn Hip-Hop history.

What We Need & What You Get

$8,000 will provide the seed money to build the foundation of the Hip-Hop Legacy of Queens, NYC, which is securing key partnerships and receiving institutional funding. Your donations will cover the expenses needed operate during this primary stage of development. Beginning in January 2013, I will be completing Phase 1: Presenting, Proposing and Securing the Partnerships with:

§  Multiple Queens Neighborhood Civic Associations

§  Queens Borough and New York City Agencies

§  Queens Art and Cultural Institutions

§  Public High Schools and Community Colleges

§  Business and Corporate Sponsors

$8,000 will accomplish two key components. They will

  1. Enable me to dedicate myself full-time to this project and still take care of my family AND
  2. Demonstrate to city agencies and potential business sponsors that the people want this project to happen and as institutions, they should pitch in their share to help bring the murals to life. 

What Do You Get?

Gratitude and art schwag. I have fine art postcards, fine art pins, I can create a digital portrait for you or you can get V.I.P. status at all Hip-Hop Legacy events, receive invitations to go on interviews...and I'm pricing out other promotional gifts to produce to show appreciation to all the folks out there who really believe this project is worthwhile, and want to be a part of something meaningful. See the perks!

The Impact

I've been out here as an artist since 2003, documenting culture in paintings, posing visual questions about societal trends, and exploring themes of love, purpose and humanity. 

The Hip-Hop Legacy of Queens, NYC is about bringing the people in deeper. Imagine what it would mean for a young artist from Southside Queens to learn how to paint and then contribute to a mural about the Lost Boyz, a Hip-Hop group from the same neighborhood? Or for visitors from Germany, Brazil and Japan coming to New York City to tour throughout Queens and see Hip-Hop murals? 

All people of all ethnicities benefit from history. Youth, seniors, people now and generation to come will benefit from the Hip-Hop Legacy of Queens, NYC. The impact is tangible, widespread and long-lasting.

Other Ways You Can Help

Donating to this Indiegogo campaign is just one thing you can do to help. Here are some other ways to stay connected to the progress of this historic project:

  • SHARE! 'Like' the Hip-Hop Legacy of Queens, NYC facebook page, repost and share updates every time they come out. Amplifying the movement allows others to join.
  • JOIN! the Inner Circle of Ambassadors and take a leadership role in supporting the project.
  • CONNECT! me to industry insiders who may be able to facilitate interviews, the collection of photographs, or additional funds to support the project.
  • CONSIDER! coming back when you get your next paycheck, and breaking me off a lil' sumthin'-sumthin ;)

SHARE! 'Like' the Hip-Hop Legacy of Queens, NYC facebook page, repost and share updates every time they come out. Amplifying the movement allows others to join.

JOIN! the Inner Circle of Ambassadors and take a leadership role in supporting the project.

CONNECT! me to industry insiders who may be able to facilitate interviews, the collection of photographs, or additional funds to support the project.

CONSIDER! coming back when you get your next paycheck, and breaking me off a lil' sumthin'-sumthin ;)

story:
The artist collective P.A.N.T.I. is on it's way to Miami!

     Comprised of Polet Guzman, Muza, NUBE, Karen Net, Yogardener & Carielen Laas; this diverse group of women with work ranging from portraiture and graffiti, to sculpture, installation and fashion, is representative of a new generation of artists in Puerto Rico. Excited by the prospect of working collectively to create awareness of a culturally rich and thriving art scene in San Juan, these women have come together to bring a sample of that scene to Miami for the week of Art Basel with an multi-sensory exhibition showcasing the participating artists latest work.  


We have pooled our resources and we have assembled a team, who have supported us by giving their time and expertise; but we still need help covering our costs!!!

 

Gallery expenses

Installation costs

Art materials

Transportation

Room & board

Printing costs

Shipping 

Insurance

etc...

 

For more information please contact us: panti@wiggiomail.com  

https://www.facebook.com/PANTI.TheCollective

story:
Our Story

In 2004 while living in Mexico, my husband and I produced a video documentary on the region's master artisans for the Mexican state of Michoacán's Casa de las Artesanias, or folk art center. That work grew into a small import business, with the goal of educating Americans about the mostly unknown artisans of Michoacán and promoting their extraordinary indigenous crafts in the United States. In the past six years we have represented numerous artisans by selling their work to galleries and museum stores and exhibiting at various prestigious crafts shows across the country. But it is the stories of the women artisans and their struggles that have touched and impressed me so deeply, that I now feel compelled to put my energies into producing an exhibit and video that focuses on these amazing women.


The Impact

The traditional crafts of the indigenous communities in Michoacán have been recognized by international folk art collectors as well as historians and experts of Mexican popular art. But this extraordinary art, most of which has been passed down from generation to generation for over 500 years, is in danger of disappearing, due to lack of commercial market. The majority of these artisans are women who struggle to support their families with earnings from the sales of their work. Their stories are powerful and compelling, as they reveal their personal struggles as girls and women living in traditional villages where women historically have had no real value. This video and exhibit will focus on four award-winning, master craftswomen who are not only creating extraordinary art, but are changing their role as women in their families and communities. We seek to promote their work to Americans who are looking for unique, handmade art that will bring beauty to their own lives and in turn will help poor hardworking women in Mexico provide for their families. Everyone who has the opportunity to meet these women and see their work is changed forever, and it is our hope that through the power of video, we can also be able to bring an inspiring experience to the viewer.


What We Need & What You Get

Money will be used to produce a 30 minute video featuring several Indigenous women artisans from Mexico, which will be shown as part of an exhibit of the artists' work to be presented in several U.S. cities.

We need funds for the video producers to travel to Mexico to shoot interviews, and to pay for post production costs, e.g. editing, subtitles,and studio sound production. We believe that it will be possible to receive support from Mexican agencies to transport the artists and their work to the U.S. for the exhibition, but we are seeking support for the production of the video/book project.

Any donation, no matter how small, is welcome!  Donors who contribute $100 or more will receive a complimentary DVD copy of the video. Those who give $200 or more will also receive a special invitation to the exhibition opening, and a 25% discount coupon towards the purchase of art from Mexico By Hand.



Other Ways You Can Help

Please share with your friends and colleagues via email and social media networks. Thank you!
