Located
in a burgeoning arts community on Broad Avenue in Memphis, Odessa is the only
gallery in Memphis that is solely focused on fostering the work and careers of
emerging artists, regardless of their age.   Our aspiration is to create a sustainable, affordable,
and inviting space for artists that are early in their careers, particularly
with regard to exhibiting work. 
Odessa is by design not prescriptive or discriminatory about a
definition of what conforms to a traditional definition of art.  Rather, we recognize the unmet need in
Memphis to broadly support the creative endeavors of a nascent, but potentially
powerful, emerging artist community.
 
Odessa
originated in Memphis in 2008. 
However, its current management has been responsible for its development
and operations since April 2010.  Ashle Bailey, recent graduate of Memphis
College of Art, was asked by a group of other forward-thinking Memphians to
head the role of Art Director for the space. Towards the end of 2010, the space  became primarily focused on the gallery
aspect of Odessa, allowing Bailey to be the lead conductor of the alternative
organization, with the help of her better half: Adam
Gilreath.  The creative couple knew
first-hand the need for such an open and non-discriminative space in Memphis,
away from the mainstream establishments that had become so
institutionalized.  In the last 12
months, Odessa has established itself as an essential member of the Memphis
arts community and is a vital component to the continued revitalization and
rebirth of the Broad Avenue Arts District. Odessa was recognized with a grant
from the Tennessee Arts Commission (via ArtsMemphis’ Arts Build Communities
program) to commission a new mural on the side of our building.
 
Odessa
produces approximately three one-night shows per month, each of which draw
upwards of forty attendees. These shows include group and solo art exhibitions,
installations, one-time-only shopping opportunities, movie screenings, and
musical showcases. Our intent is to cultivate an atmosphere that will provide
new opportunities for connecting and networking artists at all stages of their
careers.  
 
Odessa
believes that our creative community must have a regular outlet to foster
inspiration and productive dialog with the larger community.  Therefore, we purposefully program
events as often as possible to continuously create an inviting and encouraging
environment for the benefit of artists and the public alike.
 
With
the proper support, Odessa has the vision and ability to play a significant
role in shaping the future of Memphis’ arts community. Specifically: 
 
1.
Based on a successful year of programming and community-building, we believe
that we can expand our efforts and grow as an organization – which includes
diversifying our revenue streams beyond artists’ gallery fees.  Over the last year, we have only been
able to have single-night showings of each artist’s work, although we hope to
sustain a more regular gallery program with longer showings as well as regular
gallery hours. 
 
2.
We want to partner with public schools and non-profit organizations that focus
specifically on reaching out to our community’s youth to provide free gallery
exhibition opportunities to an even younger generation of emerging Memphis
artists.
 
However,
we cannot accomplish these objectives, nor sustain our commitment to our
mission of supportive emerging Memphis artists, without help from our
community. In order for Odessa to evolve while still providing our unique and
supportive environment for future generations of Memphis artists, we must have
the resources to focus on them – not our month-to-month overhead expenses.  Your contributions to our mission will
preserve an essential, arts-oriented anchor in a quickly developing urban
neighborhood while supporting a larger segment of Memphis’ creative class at
the same time. 
 
HOW YOU CAN HELP!
Currently, Odessa needs to raise enough money to sustain our organization for the remaining months of May, June, and July to ensure that the shows that have been already scheduled can proceed. Our expenses each month are as follows:




$800 for rent 


$150-$200 for utilities


$150 for cleaning supplies, toiletries, paint, spackle, and hanging supplies (gallery essentials)




This brings our total monthly expenses to $1,150.00. 

Odessa, as stated earlier, has an average of three shows per month, with a gallery rental fee of $100.00 per show.  This brings in a revenue of  roughly $300.00, which is substantially less than our monthly expenses.  Why not raise the rental fee? That is because Odessa aims to be an affordable space for emerging, and often 'starving', artists that cannot afford the space rental most other galleries charge.
With enough regular funding, we would be able to eliminate this fee all together, allowing these artists to have this experience for free. 

Please
consider becoming one of our supporters, because your help is greatly needed right
now.  Your contribution will help pay our monthly rent and utilities while allowing us to expand our
regular programming and share more of our artists’ work with a larger audience.  You will be guaranteeing a home for
experimental and ambitious creative expression in Memphis that quite literally
has nowhere else to go in our city. 
While our surrounding neighborhood continues to evolve and diversify
every week, securing a venue where ambitious art can thrive is more and more
vital.
 
Odessa fills this
need. We exist to support artists in Memphis, and we hope you will join us in
that mission.

story:
This June, three intrepid theater artists/performers from Brooklyn, Drae Campbell, Justine Williams and Eugene Ma, travel to Budapest to present an original performance piece and video work at ARTSHO, a nomadic pop-up art fest.

WHAT'S ARTSHO ALL ABOUT?

ARTSHO is an international community of artists and art enthusiasts, culture-makers and social change workers who come together each year to exchange art and ideas and to leverage the power of art, ideas and community towards a worthy cause. This year marks the fourth annual event in Budapest, after previous shows in Berlin, London and New York, where the artistic enterprise began. Every year, artists from around the world create original pieces of art inspired by ARTSHO's rotating theme. This year's theme, ACADEMIE, asks each artist to use their artistic medium to teach the ARTSHO community about something they care about or know about through their piece. A group of 30-40 local and international artists (along with even more art enthusiasts and the general public) come together for three days of art appreciating, making, sharing, meals, celebrations and arts-based activities all focused on the intersection of Art and Knowledge. 

WHAT ARE YOU COOKING UP FOR ARTSHO?

We were invited to be the first live performance to present at this unique international, interdisciplinary art event! Our performances throughout the fest will create opportunities for ARTSHO participants and audiences to come together and celebrate the immediacy of the live theatrical event. We also plan to leave behind a video-based work of art for the auction. 

We have the talent, the experience, the sparkling charisma and the drive to create a magical performance for this unique artist-powered, community-building event! We are already hard at work, creating a generous, hilarious, thought-provoking and completely ridiculous performance that uses live performance, video, powerpoint and original music to address the theme of ACADEMIE -- playfully, irreverently poking fun at the human drive to pretend that we know it all and the poetic and comic potential that arises when we admit we don't have a clue.

WHO ARE WE?

Justine Williams is an interdisciplinary artist crossing boundaries between theater, film, clown, music and community-based art. She has performed on stages regionally in the US and internationally, worked in short and feature length films as an actor, writer and/or producer, sung in bands and she regularly teaches courses in Play and Clown for fancy MFA programs, theater companies and for extraordinary everyday folk. She is a world traveler who loves collaborating and creating art with others in international contexts.

Drae Campbell is a writer, actor, director, storyteller, dancer, and nightlife emcee. In addition to winning the 2011 Miss LEZ title, Drae has been featured on Late Night with Conan O'Brien and on stages all over NYC. Her directing work has been featured in Iceland, NYC and in the San Francisco Fringe Festival. The short film she wrote and starred in, YOU MOVE ME has screened in festivals all over the world. YOU MOVE ME won the Audience Award for Outstanding Narrative Short at OUTFEST 2010. Drae was dubbed "the next lezzie comedian on the block" by AfterEllen.com for her comedic YouTube videos and her short film.

Eugene Ma is a NY-based, Hong Kong-raised, Chinese-Canadian theatre director, performer and musician. Recent directing credits include Moliere’s the Hypochondriac, Mark Ravenhill’s pool (no water), Thornton Wilder’s Childhood, and Saviana Stanescu’s Aurolac Blues. As a performer, his work has been seen on the stages of La MaMa E.T.C., St. Mark’s Church, Joe’s Pub/The Public, Mabou Mines, Ohio Theater and the Stone. Eugene is currently pursuing a teaching apprenticeship in physical comedy with comic master Christopher Bayes at the Juilliard School and Yale School of Drama, where he was guest music director for the third year actors' Commedia show, All Which Way And That. Graduate of NYU Tisch: Playwrights Horizons Theater School & Experimental Theatre Wing.

Websites

  • play-mountain.org
  • eugestage.weebly.com
  • draecampbell.com

WHERE DO I COME IN?

We need your SUPPORT to finish our piece and to get to the fest! Your donations will help cover the production costs related to creating and mounting an original performance and video work, cost of travel to and from Budapest for three artists and housing for one week. Join us in expanding our international, interdisciplinary community of culture-makers and artist/activists - you are our community too! 

For more info on ARTSHO: http://artsho.org/

PS! If the tune sounds familiar, it's a funding plea set to the tune of "Call Your Girlfriend" by Robyn. Thanks to Maha Chehlaoui, Eva Peskin and Erika Astarita for their help making the video!

story:
A HISTORY

A few years back, looking for a fun Christmas gift for my girlfriend, I decided to write her a story.  More than just a storybook, I went to some very talented photographer friends of mine and asked if they’d be willing to take a shot at creating images for the story.  I thought the best reaction would be to mail them.  The response was awesome: she loved getting them and enjoyed the experience of getting them via the mail.  So a few years later we did it again. We did it for some of our friends (new story, new images) and it went over like crazy.  The response was great, and it only made us want to do it again. 

So here we are.  That idea of writing a story and breaking it up over several postcards, postcards created exclusively for those story pieces.  I wanted to make it bigger, so this time I went to a larger group of artists I know to take on the cards.  This time, instead of two photographers, we have eight various artists, from across Canada.  I wrote the story again, and each artist chose two cards and did their magic entirely based on the words alone, no involvement from me beyond the actual story.  Any images I had in my head were only there via the story.  The actual design was all their creative voices.  Each postcard came out way beyond my expectations.  I can’t wait for you to see them. 

 

 

THE HEART

At the heart of this project is one simple idea: who doesn’t love getting mail?  Every day we go to our mailboxes and pull out bills and junk mail, stuff that doesn’t hold anything for us, nothing that speaks to who we are or what we want the world to show us.  And then on those rare days, on special occasions and random mornings, we open that same mailbox and in the midst of the other stuff there is something special: a letter from a loved one, a postcard from abroad, a piece of artwork that speaks to your soul, a package uniquely yours.  When we know those things are coming, the anticipation of those artifacts makes the mailbox something special.  When those postcards come to your door, they will be yours, for you, and will hopefully make you feel the same way we did when we made them, and when we drop them in our mailbox to send them out to you.  Something special, made for you, shared across the world and connected by our mailboxes. 

 

 

THE MIND AND THE SOUL 

There is a triangle for this to work: myself and the artists making the postcards, the lovely people of the postal service, and you; and you get the best job of them all.  You get the magic of getting them in the mail.  You get to consume this art, at random intervals, at your own schedule, as the postal service delivers. 

We set for ourselves a high bar to start, 100 sets of this series of postcards.  The cost of printing and mailing these sets out is high, not to mention the cost of the artists’ time and materials.  Our goal is to find 100 people who want to a part in our little art project. 

We’ve created some unique levels of support for you.  At the minimum, if you just want the set, there is that option available, however if you like the idea and want to go further down the mailbox with us, there are many other possibilities.

 

◦                     $2.  One Card, One Story

Thank you!  And as thanks we will select one card randomly from the set and mail that to you with a note of thanks from the author. 

 

◦                     $35.  The Postcard Set

The postcard set.  Once the set is completed and printed, we will begin mailing as soon as possible.  We will send out the cards to you one at a time as the project is intended.  If you’d prefer to get them whole as one mailing the whole set, we will accommodate.  Any cards that get wrecked or lost in transit, we will replace.  Each card is a stand-alone story, but they are all connected and we wouldn’t want you to miss out. 

 

◦                     $75.  The Postcard Book

The postcard book is a collection of the plates made for the postcards to be printed.  Each page would be dedicated to the image of the card, in postcard size.  The opposing page would be the story that accompanies that image.  Each book will have a personal note from the author thanking you for your support.

 

◦                     $100.  Combo Pack 

You want the postcards, but the book would be cool, how do you decide?  Easy: take them both.  Supporters wanting both options can get it here, and we’ll make you a deal on them.  The best deal of them all!

 

◦                     $150.  The Postcard Book – Special Edition 

The postcard book is a collection of the plates made for the postcards to be printed.  Each page would be dedicated to the image of the card, in postcard size.  The opposing page would be the story that accompanies that image.  Each book will have a personal note from the author thanking you for your support.  

But wait, there’s more! (I cannot believe I typed that…)  Above and beyond the note of thanks from the author, we will get each artist to sign their respective pages.  And with the difficulty of getting all of the artists to sign these, with them all spread across the country, these special editions will be limited to only 10 copies. 

 

◦                     $250.  The Artist’s Image

Supporters at this level will receive the postcard set.  Once they’ve received them, they will be able to select the postcard of their choice to be printed as a stretched canvas piece (16”x20”) with an accompanying title card that will have the story on it.  The prints will be artist signed and the author will sign the title card.  A great artistic piece for your home!

 

 

THE VOICE

We thank you very much for your time and consideration of our art project.  If you are interested in supporting this project and getting involved, we can’t wait to get to know you.  If you can’t contribute, but still wish to help, please let as many people as you can know about it.  We’d love to spread this art project as far abroad as possible, and any help you can offer to spread the word will also be greatly appreciated.  

Feel free to fire me any questions and we will answer them all in a timely fashion and fill you in on all the ongoings of this very unique project.  The work of these artists is spectacular and it would be a shame for you not to see them. 

 

Thanks for your time.

Gilbert

story:
Short Summary

Simone Frank was born in Toronto in 1970 and resided in Mississauga until she attended Ryerson University. There, she achieved a Bachelor of Applied Arts in Fashion Design in 1993. She is a Dean’s list graduate of Graphic Design from George Brown College in 2009. She also holds a certificate from writing from Humber College, 2003.

She has been exhibiting since 1991 in solo and group exhibitions in Toronto, the GTA, Tokyo and also in St. Vincent, W.I. where her family is from. Recently, she was invited to exhibit her works of art in China.

In St. Vincent she had three solo exhibitions at Lambii’s Yatch Club on Union Island and Singer Gallery in Kingstown, St. Vincent. She has had solo exhibitions at Singer Fragipani Hotel in Bequai, which is owned and operated by the Prime Minister’s daughter. She was interviewed twice on the radio while there. In Toronto she exhibited at Toronto City Hall. Her gallery solo exhibitions were at BAND, Skeir Gallery, Artist Awake and A Space Windows. She exhibited at Toronto City Hall. Her work is part of the Chinese Canadian Business Association’s collection in Toronto.

In July, 2000, she suffered a near-fatal allergy which lead to a three month hospital stay in intensive care. She also lives with Lupus, a chronic illness that affects the immune system.

She has received a Toronto Arts Council Exhibition Assistance grant in 1994 and 1997 and the Ontario Arts Council Writer’s Reserve grant in 1997.

Simone Frank taught private art classes from her studio called Soul Designs for several years until she taught for the Toronto Board of Education’s ACE Program in 1988. That year she was also published in Litté Realité, then later in Word Magazine 2002 and Anonymous Cheese in 2006, which was published by the Mississauga Arts Council.

She resides in Toronto, Canada.

Simone Frank needs financial assistance so that she can travel to Asia to exhibit her works of art.

What We Need & What You Get

The monies raised will be allocated to:

A new passport

Chinese Working Visa

Shipping the Art to China

Travel

Accommodations

Clothes

Mandarin Lessons

Brokerage Fees

Marketing Fees

And hopefully a new computer

The one I’m writing you from is barely alive.

 

If I don’t reach my goal, I will spend the money to fund a series of art local art exhibitions and projects on the go.

I am working on a short film called, ‘Get Up.’ It is written and the dialogue has been recorded. It will be submitted as installations piece with supported visual. It speaks to depression and the argues about a sick person’s responsibility to the community surrounding illness.

I am also the process of turning a completed novel called, No More Kissing Frogs about online dating, into a graphic novel and a screenplay.

A Soulful Senior's Moment is a graphic novel that must be published which will raise funds for Mid Toronto Community Serviees, an organization that supports the elderly in Toronto by bringing them meals, teaching them art, advocating on their behalf and creating a safe social environment for them, among other things. (You can preview the book in the media section of Indiegogo.

There is also a piece of creative non-fiction in the works called, Morphine Dreams­. This book illustrates the walk I took through the Health Care System in Canada. It has taken twelve years to write, and I would also like to turn that into a script.

Normally, I work full-time to produce the art I create, but I due to health issues, full-time work has become to great a challenge.

 

The Impact

Two years ago, my mother passed away. A friend of mine who had lost his parents told me that when your parent’s die, it makes you want to be a better person. And he was right.

I have worked harder in the past two years than perhaps is all my life to fill the void of losing the one person who could always talk me out of depression. When I was hospitalized with a severe drug reaction referred to as TEN, in 2001, my mother visited me every day in the Burn Unit of Sunnybrook Hospital.  And when the symptoms of Lupus began to appear, she took me in and protected me from the struggles of the world. She encouraged me to return to school, which I did. A challenge for a person who had been in a drug induced coma for two months and had her skin removed and re-grown. I also had numerous operations including two tracheotomies. I had to learn to walk again, to breathe again. I have lost my hair several times either due to Lupus of the medications I take and I struggle to survive.

When Mom was diagnosed with cancer, I moved in with her until it was time to place her in palliative care. I visited her each day as she had done for me, commuting two hours each way from my new job to her home in a suburb of Toronto and then to palliative care.

Perhaps it was the stresses of caring for her, working full-time and commuting that lead to my recent hospital stay. I have struggled to live with Lupus since I was diagnosed in 2004. I work hard to manage the pain. The illness presents as joint swelling, rashes, organ failure, anxiety and bone deterioration when it is active. I often wonder how much longer I have to live, but try not to think about it.

My father has Parkinson’s disease and diabetes. And after my Mother died, the family unit just fell apart.

The only way I have ever been able to live positively despite all that has happened to me, is to plan far into the future and to dream big.

Guess what? It paid off. I am invited to exhibit in China this year from late April to mid July.

I will send anyone who makes a contribute a small piece of art as a token of appreciation. Simply send me an email at simone4king (at) gmail.com with 'You Deserve It,' in the subject heading, and I will email you a thank you that you can print off and frame.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

They are throwing a fundraiser on April 3rd. I will be painting live there are giving part of the proceed from 'Solid' and 'Smokin'" -- Jimi Hendrix portraits, to them. The rest will help with mny trip.

https://secure.midtoronto.com/default.aspx?CCID=15&L=2&MSP=126

Idiegogo tells me that some people can’t contribute but might be able to help. So perhaps you have a great working iPad that you wouldn’t mind parting with, or you can sponsor me by donating a new mac. These things would be really helpful. I also haven’t been able to afford a keyboard. The one I used to attach to my computer wore out. If you have an APAG1 that’s collecting dust. Perhaps you are able to provide free food or alcohol at my fundraisers. Perhaps your company is able to provide a discount on clothes…

If you'd like to volunteer language lessons, legal services, brokerage fees or provide a discount on shipping. It must be via UPS, I will greatly appreciate it.

Perhaps you've been waiting for the perfect time to buy a work of art from me. Would you mind buying it now?

I will send anyone who makes a contribute a small piece of art as a token of appreciation. Simply send me an email at simone4king (at) gmail.com.

Or at the very least, please pass this on. I would really like to be able to take this trip with my niece who misses her grandmother as much as I.

 

Thanks for your time!

 

Simone

htp://www.simonefrank.com

http://simone4king.blogspot.ca
story_txt:
Short Summary
Simone Frank was born in Toronto in 1970 and resided in Mississauga until she attended Ryerson University. There, she achieved a Bachelor of Applied Arts in Fashion Design in 1993. She is a Dean’s list graduate of Graphic Design from George Brown College in 2009. She also holds a certificate from writing from Humber College, 2003.
She has been exhibiting since 1991 in solo and group exhibitions in Toronto, the GTA, Tokyo and also in St. Vincent, W.I. where her family is from. Recently, she was invited to exhibit her works of art in China.
In St. Vincent she had three solo exhibitions at Lambii’s Yatch Club on Union Island and Singer Gallery in Kingstown, St. Vincent. She has had solo exhibitions at Singer Fragipani Hotel in Bequai, which is owned and operated by the Prime Minister’s daughter. She was interviewed twice on the radio while there. In Toronto she exhibited at Toronto City Hall. Her gallery solo exhibitions were at BAND, Skeir Gallery, Artist Awake and A Space Windows. She exhibited at Toronto City Hall. Her work is part of the Chinese Canadian Business Association’s collection in Toronto.
In July, 2000, she suffered a near-fatal allergy which lead to a three month hospital stay in intensive care. She also lives with Lupus, a chronic illness that affects the immune system.
She has received a Toronto Arts Council Exhibition Assistance grant in 1994 and 1997 and the Ontario Arts Council Writer’s Reserve grant in 1997.
Simone Frank taught private art classes from her studio called Soul Designs for several years until she taught for the Toronto Board of Education’s ACE Program in 1988. That year she was also published in Litté Realité, then later in Word Magazine 2002 and Anonymous Cheese in 2006, which was published by the Mississauga Arts Council.
She resides in Toronto, Canada.
Simone Frank needs financial assistance so that she can travel to Asia to exhibit her works of art.


What We Need & What You Get
The monies raised will be allocated to:
A new passport
Chinese Working Visa
Shipping the Art to China
Travel
Accommodations
Clothes
Mandarin LessonsBrokerage Fees
Marketing Fees
And hopefully a new computer
The one I’m writing you from is barely alive.
 
If I don’t reach my goal, I will spend the money to fund a series of art local art exhibitions and projects on the go.
I am working on a short film called, ‘Get Up.’ It is written and the dialogue has been recorded. It will be submitted as installations piece with supported visual. It speaks to depression and the argues about a sick person’s responsibility to the community surrounding illness.
I am also the process of turning a completed novel called, No More Kissing Frogs about online dating, into a graphic novel and a screenplay.
A Soulful Senior's Moment is a graphic novel that must be published which will raise funds for Mid Toronto Community Serviees, an organization that supports the elderly in Toronto by bringing them meals, teaching them art, advocating on their behalf and creating a safe social environment for them, among other things. (You can preview the book in the media section of Indiegogo.
There is also a piece of creative non-fiction in the works called, Morphine Dreams­. This book illustrates the walk I took through the Health Care System in Canada. It has taken twelve years to write, and I would also like to turn that into a script.
Normally, I work full-time to produce the art I create, but I due to health issues, full-time work has become to great a challenge.
 


The Impact
Two years ago, my mother passed away. A friend of mine who had lost his parents told me that when your parent’s die, it makes you want to be a better person. And he was right.
I have worked harder in the past two years than perhaps is all my life to fill the void of losing the one person who could always talk me out of depression. When I was hospitalized with a severe drug reaction referred to as TEN, in 2001, my mother visited me every day in the Burn Unit of Sunnybrook Hospital.  And when the symptoms of Lupus began to appear, she took me in and protected me from the struggles of the world. She encouraged me to return to school, which I did. A challenge for a person who had been in a drug induced coma for two months and had her skin removed and re-grown. I also had numerous operations including two tracheotomies. I had to learn to walk again, to breathe again. I have lost my hair several times either due to Lupus of the medications I take and I struggle to survive.
When Mom was diagnosed with cancer, I moved in with her until it was time to place her in palliative care. I visited her each day as she had done for me, commuting two hours each way from my new job to her home in a suburb of Toronto and then to palliative care.
Perhaps it was the stresses of caring for her, working full-time and commuting that lead to my recent hospital stay. I have struggled to live with Lupus since I was diagnosed in 2004. I work hard to manage the pain. The illness presents as joint swelling, rashes, organ failure, anxiety and bone deterioration when it is active. I often wonder how much longer I have to live, but try not to think about it.
My father has Parkinson’s disease and diabetes. And after my Mother died, the family unit just fell apart.
The only way I have ever been able to live positively despite all that has happened to me, is to plan far into the future and to dream big.
Guess what? It paid off. I am invited to exhibit in China this year from late April to mid July.
I will send anyone who makes a contribute a small piece of art as a token of appreciation. Simply send me an email at simone4king (at) gmail.com with 'You Deserve It,' in the subject heading, and I will email you a thank you that you can print off and frame.
 

Other Ways You Can Help
They are throwing a fundraiser on April 3rd. I will be painting live there are giving part of the proceed from 'Solid' and 'Smokin'" -- Jimi Hendrix portraits, to them. The rest will help with mny trip.
https://secure.midtoronto.com/default.aspx?CCID=15&L=2&MSP=126
Idiegogo tells me that some people can’t contribute but might be able to help. So perhaps you have a great working iPad that you wouldn’t mind parting with, or you can sponsor me by donating a new mac. These things would be really helpful. I also haven’t been able to afford a keyboard. The one I used to attach to my computer wore out. If you have an APAG1 that’s collecting dust. Perhaps you are able to provide free food or alcohol at my fundraisers. Perhaps your company is able to provide a discount on clothes…
If you'd like to volunteer language lessons, legal services, brokerage fees or provide a discount on shipping. It must be via UPS, I will greatly appreciate it.
Perhaps you've been waiting for the perfect time to buy a work of art from me. Would you mind buying it now?
I will send anyone who makes a contribute a small piece of art as a token of appreciation. Simply send me an email at simone4king (at) gmail.com.
Or at the very least, please pass this on. I would really like to be able to take this trip with my niece who misses her grandmother as much as I.
 
Thanks for your time!
 
Simone

http://simone4king.blogspot.ca

story:
UPDATE!!  I will bring this sculpture to Burning Man to share it with the citizens of Black Rock City, before installing it at the museum!  Please help me make this happen -- let's bring this dream into reality!

 

Hello, and thanks for visiting my FertiliTree Campaign, to create a 15' sculpture for the American Museum of Ceramic Art in Pomona!  This is our second Indiegogo campaign for this project (thus "FertiliTree 2"), and now with AMOCA's full backing we're sure to get the support needed to make this happen!.

I've been a sculptor for about 7 years now.  I worked in the corporate world for 15 years in Industrial Design  until I quit that in ‘04 to devote myself to art.  First I traveled through Thailand and India for a year, studying meditation and yoga, and filling my creative spirit with inspiration from all the ancient art and architecture.  I returned with a desire to express fundamental truths about our human nature through my artworks.  The FertiliTree will be my greatest expression of this to date.

Usually people wait until their campaign is complete before beginning the project, but I will be building this sculpture while the campaign is running, and will have it completed and ready for installation by the end.  I'll be documenting the whole process, both the fundraising and the construction, to lay a roadmap for other artists to follow in creating their own monumental public art pieces!

 
The FertiliTree will be planted near the entrance of the museum’s new location in Pomona, just east of Los Angeles.   Pomona is the Roman goddess of fruit trees, of abundance, fruitfulness, and fertility, and so I used these themes to guide the design of the sculpture.  FertiliTree has no branches and leaves, but she’ll bear fruits of inspiration, wonder, and pleasure in the hearts of all who see her! 
 
The sculpture grows upwards from a tree trunk into a female form (I still need to work on the trunk shape a bit.)  She's holding a mandala blossom pattern, representing consciousness.  This piece expresses the fertile evolution and flow of Life, upwards from inanimate vegetation, through animals, and into humans, through which conscious self-awareness arises, so that the Universe may know Itself, through us.
 
 

Several views of the 3D CAD model

The model of the piece shown above is a rough computer sketch– the final sculpture will have far more detail, color, and nuanced expression, like the Seeds have, and my Labradorite Priestess below

The FertiliTree will be by far the largest and most ambitious project I've attempted.   Not only will it be a great step for my artistic path as a wonderful addition to the museums collection and to the city of Pomona, but it also has the potential to make a huge difference in the world, as a model for community-based funding of public art pieces, combined with a very economic fabrication method! 

Public art makes a place feel loved and cared for, transforming the cities we live in from primarily functional, utilitarian spaces to places of genuine beauty, inspiration, and joy, which the world could sure use a lot more of! 

Up until now almost all public art has been created thru a very top-down approach, with some large organization providing the funds and the location for a public artwork.  If we can successfully decouple the funding from the location, this can blow open the doors to the manifestation of a lot more art in our cities, institutions, and our lives.

For public works, I've developed a unique process of filling the ceramic sections with concrete when the piece is installed, making it extremely strong and resilient. This overcomes the issue of fragility that has kept ceramics from being more widely employed in public art.  With this method we can eventually build sculptures 25-50-100 ft. tall, for a fraction of the cost of other public art fabrication methods. 

They can be elaborately sculpted in a 3D modelling program, giving a very wide range of creative expressions.  Plus, the available glazes offer an extraordinary range of color possibilities, far more and far more durable than classic public art surface treatments.

Antoni Gaudi used ceramic elements and mosaics in his construction of Parc Guell and many other buildings in Barcelona 100 years ago, which are just as beautiful today as they were when they were first made, demonstrating the environmental resilience of glazed surfaces.  This new method I’ve developed, of filling hollow ceramic forms with concrete, can be much more versatile,  economical, and swift, since the form for the concrete is the ceramic itself!

Parc Guell, one of Gaudi's masterpieces in Barcelona

 

THANK YOU GIFTS FOR YOUR DONATION

Here are a samples of the Seeds you’ll be able to choose for your reward.  You can choose one of the below designs, or I will make a unique custom piece for you -- just tell me which colors you like.

These will be available as Full Seeds, made of two halves attached together, or Half Seeds, which are just the front side, open on the back.  Half Seeds may be hung on your wall, and both types may be displayed on your desk, a mantle, a window ledge or altar, or wherever else you'd like to place this unique piece of art.

SINGLE COLOR SEEDS OF THE FERTILITREE

$50 FOR A HALF-SEED, $75 FOR A FULL SEED

 

 

TWO COLOR SEEDS OF THE FERTILITREE

$75 FOR A HALF-SEED, $100 FOR A FULL SEED

 

 

2' SEEDS OF THE FERTILITREE 

$300 FOR A SINGLE COLOR, $500 FOR TWO OR MORE COLORS

 

 

 

WATER FEATURES, 3' TALL, YOURS FOR A $2,000 DONATION

You can see a video of them in action here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sTzWnFJxiQI

 
In addition, everyone who pledges $50 or more will have their name inscribed in the trunk of the FertiliTree!  I'll be building the sculpture during the campaign, so this is only available to those who pledge before I complete the trunk section, which should be by early July.
 

Please join me in bringing the FertiliTree to life!!  Also, it would be massively helpful if you would share this project with just a few other people.  Please forward this to some art lovers in your life -- this will spread the word far farther than I could hope to do alone.

Thank you all SO MUCH for supporting my creative passions, and for contributing to the beautification of our World.

PROJECT GOALS:

- Fund the complete construction and installation of FertiliTree, at 15’
- Fund the crafting and shipping of all rewards to donors
- Help establish a model for community-based, grass-roots funding of public art pieces
- Create a monumental public sculpture using this revolutionary fabrication technique to demonstrate it’s potential and possibilities
- Disseminate both the funding model and the technique out into the world so that far more artists can make creative use of them to support their art and their lives.
- Inspire and support the creation of many more public art pieces.
- Spread my art into the lives of many more people.
- Support my creative efforts, both directly thru Indiegogo funding, and through developing opportunities to create many more sculptural installations

story:
7th Annual ARTspiration! Community Arts Festival

The Fleisher Art Memorial will host the 7th Annual ARTspiration!Community Arts Festival on Saturday, June 8, 2013.  This beloved, free street fair has provided an accessible entryway into the arts for Philadelphians who are not familiar with Fleisher’s programs or art-making in general.  ARTspiration! showcases Fleisher’s studio art classes, exhibitions and community programs while celebrating South Philadelphia’s rich cultural resources. Through art, this multicultural, intergenerational event brings together the diverse communities of Fleisher’s surrounding neighborhood.

The Artist in Us All

ARTspiration! has become one of Fleisher’s most anticipated events with attendance often exceeding 2000 guests.  We are grateful for the many members of the Fleisher community, including our volunteers, students and faculty, who make ARTspiration! a success each year.  This free annual event would not be possible without your hard work and dedication.  

In order to provide artmaking opportunities for even more Philadelphians this year, Fleisher has set a goal to raise $2,500 to support the 7th Annual ARTspiration! Festival.  Funds raised from this campaign will allow Fleisher to host ARTspiration! at no cost to attendees in accordance with Fleisher's mission to make art accessible to everyone regardless of economic means, background, or artistic experience.

When you make a contribution of $10 or more, your name will be included on the Donor Wall at ARTspiration!  Individuals who donate more than $10 will also receive one or more limited edition thank you gifts.  All thank you gifts must be claimed at the ARTspiration! Festival on June 8.

Art Enriches the Community

Each year Ruby Stricker, who lives across the street from Fleisher, attends the day-long festival with her little sister.  “ARTspiration! was very, very fun!  My weekend was wonderful after it,” said Ruby after last year’s event.  “I was really impressed with the event and the crowd you managed to pull in!  As a resident of Queen Village, I’m personally very pleased to see it go off so well,” said Thomas Stanley, attendee and participant at last year’s event.  Fleisher looks forward to strengthening community ties and enriching the lives of Philadelphians through art once again at the 7th Annual ARTspiration! Festival.

story:
About Our Campaign

My name is Lauren Goodwin and I am the owner of a recently established portrait photography business called Rhino Photography. I am also the house photographer for Asylum 13, a weekly goth/industrial event run in Northern Delaware, which provides a kink friendly environment for those involved in and those who are curious about exploring alternative lifestyles; in which they can come together in a safe place and meet like-minded individuals.

The lifestyle promoted at Asylum 13 has recently been introduced to mainstream society, and not in a positive light. A harsh portrayal of women permeates this view, brought about by a judgmental media and recent popular fads that inaccurately portray alternative lifestyles, such as the novel _Fifty Shades of Grey_. I wish to show people a more positive (and accurate) view of this world, one in which women, no matter what their role, are shown as the healthy, strong and beautiful creatures that they are.

Therefore, we bring you the Women of Asylum 13 Calendar, an expressive collection devoted showing the women in this lifestyle at their best and most beautiful. Thank you for your support.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising funds in the amount of $4,000 to print an initial run of 100 calendars as well as upgrade my extremely old, out of date digital SLR camera body in order to create the quality of images this work deserves.

  • $2,199 for camera body
  • $1,000 for first run of 100 full color, glossy calendars
  • $800 for models, hair, makeup, wardrobe

Every dollar helps so please don't feel any contribution is too small. We are offering many perks ranging from hugs all the way to a portrait photo session by yours truly. We understand what we are creating is not for everyone, which is why I am offering alternate rewards in the way of gift certificates and photo shoots of your choice.

Even if we don't reach our goal, your contribution will be used towards this project even if it takes longer than our desired goal.

The Impact

With your help, we can combat the negative mainstream view of the lifestyle we find so open-minded and full of love and support. 

Your contribution is also crucial in helping my business get off the ground and fulfilling my life long dream of turning my hobby into a sustainable, sucessful career. Please help me save my soul. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute by way of money, we understand. But please, please share this with your friends and help us get the word out there.

Please use the share tools at the top for Facebook and Twitter.

Thank you so much. You're all awesome!!!

story:
The Dream:

 

Our names are David and Mandy Anderson.  We have a dream of opening our own photography studio/vintage style store in the Portland, Oregon / Vancouver, Washington area and you can help!

About David Anderson:

David has had a passion for photography that goes back to his youth, and has slowly been making it a career.  Working with local models, businesses, and other artists, he has built a constantly expanding client base. 

Currently he shoots at his home, in a converted garage studio in Battle Ground, Washington or at a co-op studio he shares with several other photographers in SE Portland, Oregon. His enthusiasm and talent shows through in his extraordinary work and with his own studio, things can only get better.

Check out his website here and see for yourself!

About Mandy Anderson:

Mandy has spent many years running the office of a local distributorship/retail store.  Her experience in business has taught her much about marketing, customer service and accounting.  Running her own store would be a dream come true, and her love for art helps fuel and support David's passion for photography.  She has a small side business making jewelry, which she has fused together with David's photographs to make many unique and creative items.

Look at them here!


What We Need & What You Get

To make this dream a reality, our biggest stumbling block is raising the money for studio/retail space. We currently operate out of a co-op photography studio, but the scheduling is tricky. We need a good location, with lots of foot traffic to guarantee our success!  If we can raise money above and beyond, it will go towards new lights, backgrounds and studio equipment as well as store set up and inventory.

Here's where we start:

  • Minimum of $3000 to get our foot in the door.
  • Store set up (clothing racks, shelves, signage, etc.) $2000

In return, we have gifts available from signed prints and jewelry, to full studio photo sessions!


    The Impact

    In addition, we plan to give local artists a place to showcase their work.  Incorporating paintings, photographs and creations into our décor will not only give them a chance to showcase their work but a chance to sell them as well.  Local crafters and vintage collectors will also be approached and encouraged to consign their items in our store.

      Once the ball is rolling, we hope to have a monthly local artist showcase, inviting the community to view a featured artist's work.  It will be an opportunity to reach out to the community, encourage creativity and support art in our neighborhood. The event would have local musicians, refreshments and would be free, with a suggested donation to either a local art program or the local food bank.

        Risks & Challenges

        Starting a brick and mortar business is a big endeavor, but with your support we hope to increase our chances of success.

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Can't contribute?  We understand! 

        You can still help by spreading the word and getting our campaign out there.  Please tell your friends and share our story!
story_txt:
The Dream: Our names are David and Mandy Anderson.  We have a dream of opening our own photography studio/vintage style store in the Portland, Oregon / Vancouver, Washington area and you can help!
About David Anderson:
David has had a passion for photography that goes back to his youth, and has slowly been making it a career.  Working with local models, businesses, and other artists, he has built a constantly expanding client base.  
Currently he shoots at his home, in a converted garage studio in Battle Ground, Washington or at a co-op studio he shares with several other photographers in SE Portland, Oregon. His enthusiasm and talent shows through in his extraordinary work and with his own studio, things can only get better.
Check out his website here and see for yourself!
About Mandy Anderson:
Mandy has spent many years running the office of a local distributorship/retail store.  Her experience in business has taught her much about marketing, customer service and accounting.  Running her own store would be a dream come true, and her love for art helps fuel and support David's passion for photography.  She has a small side business making jewelry, which she has fused together with David's photographs to make many unique and creative items.
Look at them here!
   What We Need & What You Get To make this dream a reality, our biggest stumbling block is raising the money for studio/retail space. We currently operate out of a co-op photography studio, but the scheduling is tricky. We need a good location, with lots of foot traffic to guarantee our success!  If we can raise money above and beyond, it will go towards new lights, backgrounds and studio equipment as well as store set up and inventory.Here's where we start: 
Minimum of $3000 to get our foot in the door. Store set up (clothing racks, shelves, signage, etc.) $2000 In return, we have gifts available from signed prints and jewelry, to full studio photo sessions!
  The Impact In addition, we plan to give local artists a place to showcase their work.  Incorporating paintings, photographs and creations into our décor will not only give them a chance to showcase their work but a chance to sell them as well.  Local crafters and vintage collectors will also be approached and encouraged to consign their items in our store. Once the ball is rolling, we hope to have a monthly local artist showcase, inviting the community to view a featured artist's work.  It will be an opportunity to reach out to the community, encourage creativity and support art in our neighborhood. The event would have local musicians, refreshments and would be free, with a suggested donation to either a local art program or the local food bank.
  Risks & Challenges Starting a brick and mortar business is a big endeavor, but with your support we hope to increase our chances of success.
  Other Ways You Can Help Can't contribute?  We understand! 
You can still help by spreading the word and getting our campaign out there.  Please tell your friends and share our story!

story:
Short Summary

The Walk of Art Kids project represents an arts and educational component, of the Walk of Art Inc. organization, that through liaisons with community organizations and local schools, provide a first rate, hands on arts education experience for children. The goal of the project is to establish more art programs in schools and low income neighborhoods where it is severely lacking. We aim to bring arts education back to NYC Public Schools, beginning with Brooklyn. We structured a project that would be attractive and beneficial to kids and artists alike. The project will entail street art tours and workshops given by teaching artists and program instructors.

In an attempt to add diversity to our project, we have recruited ten teaching artists throughout New York City, paired them with program instructors and developed a series of ten street art workshops each varying in technique, development and artistry. Our project will begin in the beginning of 2015 and be held at a number of galleries, community centers and public spaces conveniently located in the low-income neighborhoods in Brooklyn that are critically lacking proper art programs in public schools.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for monetary support to help us reach our goal of ten thousand dollars for the cost of supplies, gallery rental and compensation for the teaching artists and program instructors. This support will allow us to successfully conduct our project without any uncertainty on how to pay for materials and proper instruction.This project will allow us to provide dedicated art education instruction in neighborhoods and schools, in a time where art classes have become expendable and are seen as nonessential.

The Impact

We recently began partnering with schools in low income neighborhoods to pair artists with children with special needs, with hopes to assist in their development in the classroom as well as out of the classroom.

Meet One of Our Students: Thomas is a young man from the South Bronx. He is in the sixth grade and attends the local public school in his area. In the last year, Thomas has had some challenges in school keeping up with his schoolwork. His teachers believe that although he is very bright, his inability to achieve high grades results from a lack of focus and concentration in class. 

Thomas came to a Walk of Art Workshop earlier this year and found his passion for learning and achieving high marks, but it wasn’t in a traditional classroom - it was through art. 

Thomas’s Interaction time with artists helped him learn basic painting and creative rules and he began to develop his own art works as well as forged a relationship between art, artists and his community. Thomas has learned the profound pleasure of self-expression and the satisfaction that comes with acquiring knowledge and developing new skills he can apply to enhancing his neighborhood and his own life. 

During the past year, Thomas has started to apply the concepts he learned in our workshop to his school work. His parents and teachers have started seeing a change in his behavior and focus. His grades are improving and he has a new outlook on the idea of finishing what he starts and using his passion to both traditional and non-traditional ways of learning. 

Thomas is just one of our students but we have dozens of similar stories about how art inspires and influences children to do better and have more focus in their lives and communities. This is why we need to continue doing the work that we do and we need your help whether it be monetarily or by simply spreading the word about our cause.

story:
After five years of running the magazine out of Belgium as a freely distributed title, time is ripe to grow some balls and play with the big boys. What this means? A renewed editorial focus, international expansion, a paid circulation and an entirely revisited format. The thing is, together with our dreams of world domination comes a very real need to fund the revolution. And what better way to buff the coffers up than by calling upon our loyal army of Word warriors (you!) for dollar-dollar-bill donations.

So, staying within the times, we’ve put together a month-long crowd-funding campaign with the objective of raising $27,000. How do we hope to hit the target? Well, we’ve concocted a range of different “support packages” in return for your humble donations. Starting at $6 and going up to $1,400, you’ll be able to get everything from your name printed in our next edition and a copy of our never-seen-before dummy issue to yearly subscriptions to the magazine and a framed and signed 70 x 120 print of your favourite Word cover ever. What’s more, we also will be introducing exclusive and limited “pop-up packages” during the campaign with gifts from our friends and family (a signed out-of-print Dirk Braeckman book, a commission with Sarah Eechaut, records from Dandelion Lotus Records and On-Point Records and much more), just to keep you on your toes.

Yes, this is us asking for money. But this is also your cue to show us some love and ensure we can give The Word Magazine the resources needed to go global. Fear not though, we’re still big on the smaller things in life, still dedicated to spotting and supporting creative and artistic talent and still intent on giving unique people, places and passions a voice. The only difference is that we’re going for a wider and tighter playing field.

The packages

The Like Level ($40)

Our first edition of 2013 delivered wherever you are in the world. A limited-edition pack of 10 The Word stickers + Your name printed in the first edition as a patron of The Word.

The love Level ($70)

A yearly subscription to The Word in 2013 (two editions). A limited-edition pack of 10 The Word stickers + Your name printed in the first edition as a patron of The Word.

The Live Level ($200)

A copy of our hand-numbered photobook. An unpublished copy of our dummy issue. A yearly subscription to The Word in 2013 (two editions). A limited-edition pack of 10 The Word stickers + Your name printed in the first edition as a patron of The Word.

The Photography Bundle ($250)

Clockwise from top left: A yearly subscription (2 issues) to the magazine, the chance to commission Word photographer Sarah Eechaut for a portrait of your choice, an autographed copy of Dirk Braeckman's out-of-print book, as well as signed, first-print artist editions culled from Le Caillou Bleu's archive.

The Limited Level ($650)

A signed and numbered 50x70 unframed print of our first edition’s cover. A copy of our hand-numbered photobook. An unpublished copy of our dummy issue. A yearly subscription to The Word in 2013 (two editions). A limited-edition pack of 10 The Word stickers + Your name printed in the first edition as a patron of The Word.

Going international

As off April 2013, the magazine will be available in all major European cities (Paris, London, Amsterdam, Berlin, Rome, Milan, Barcelona, etc.) as well as in the United States (New York and Los Angeles) and Asia (Tokyo, Hong Kong, Seoul and Shanghai). You’ll be able to pick a copy up at specialist newssagents and bookstores, museum and gallery shops, concept stores and selected record stores.

Free is dead

Instead of bending over backwards for advertisers, we much prefer doing so for our readers. Yes, that means you’ll now need to pay for a magazine some of you have been used to receiving for free for the past five years but, believe us, we’ll give you good reasons to.

Two new sections

If you also read us online you’ll have noticed that photography and the arts have grown to become ever more important to our editorial mix. This, we felt, deserved to be set in stone with the addition of two dedicated sections. Unearthing the underbelly of photography and the arts, we’ll document the art forms themselves just as much as we will the people behind them. About, for and by the people if you will.

Two editions per year

In a world where everything moves so quickly and a story becomes irrelevant the minute the “publish” button is hit, we’ll be slowing things down a notch in 2013. Two editions instead of five, giving ourselves more time to handcraft the kind of stories and features that deserve to be printed. The first edition will come out in April 2013, and the second one will hit newsstands come October.

New format and design

We couldn’t possibly tighten the magazine’s editorial purpose, export it internationally and put it on sale without giving its design a complete make-over: a new format (slightly smaller), a new paper and a new design.

What’s next?

A bunch of stuff! First, we’ll be celebrating our fifth anniversary with a small do on 22nd February. We’ll also be launching, on the same night, a hand-numbered photo book which captures five years of Word photography. Then it’s back to work to get our Second Best Edition to the printers in time for its official release on 8th April.

Partners

A special extra thank you goes out to the following partners who’ve all helped in their own way to give this campaign the platforms it needs to be a success.

       

   

Thank you’s

An extra special thanks goes out to Vuurwerk for letting us use their phenomenal track “Bad Habits” on our little video (it’s taken from their “Me” EP which is available as a free download here) and to Bruno Tracq for the quick-turnaround editing job.

story:
Ladies and Gentlemen! Boys and Girls! Children of all Ages!
Welcome to the "Mad Scientist Lab" Acquisition Drive!

My name is Doctor Soul and I am an artist attempting to work in multiple fields, trying to see what wonderful and whimsical things I can create!

The majority of my past work has been predominately computer based; I chose this because it allowed me to create without the restraints of cost being involved but it has one major limitation: it's not physical. Being the lover of making things that other people can enjoy I am attempting to expand my workspace so I have the ability to make more unique products. The type of things I am working on, outside of the incentives provided here, are as follows:

Prop Replicas, Jewelry, Costumes, Masks, 2D Artwork, Animations, Figures, Health Improvement Formulas, and More!

Seems like an odd list, but each item has a plan laid out! By supporting this project you will be assisting in providing a space to allow all the above to be created!

 


PERKS!
-- "I Support Mad Scientist!"  Vinyl Decals!  I have a vinyl plotter and make these myself; it's one of the many enjoyable things I can do!

A Decal will be included with each order of $15 or more!


-- Glow-in-the-Dark "TGRI" Pendant
If you know those initials, you know what these are fashioned after!
I use a very high percentage of the most powerful Glow-in-the-Dark Powder: Alkaline Rare Earth Metal Silicate-Aluminate Oxide Europium Doped! It has a Very Long (24+ hours) Glow in the Dark effect!
-- TGRI Pendants body measure 1.5 inches tall (1.65" ttl)


-- LE Chrysalis Pendant
Each Chrysalis Resin Pendant color will be limited to a production of 100 each!
Series 1 contains the following colors
- Glow in the Dark (Blind Bags Only!)
- Orange
- White
- Blue
- Purple
- Pink
- Yellow
- Pearl
- Midnight Blue
- Neon Green
-  Black

-- Chrysalis Pendants body measure two inches tall (2.27" total.)
50 of each color will in the blind Bag batch!
Estimated odds for each color: 1:11

Want to be guaranteed to get the color you want? I've made the option available here: http://www.storenvy.com/products/2666547-chrysalis-pendants-s1
(I put them in the above link instead of in the campaign due to no better option here for doing multiple Limited Edition options!)


- Large "TGRI" Pocket Prop Container
With a similar TGRI appearance these containers are perfect for adding to any Steampunk, Scientist or Cosplay ensemble!
These containers have a cast resin top and bottom with a clear vial between that can be unscrewed from the top. This will allow you to add a variety of items like ooze, liquid, herbs or  anything else you want!  I am recreating the mold to make it look better when cast and make the surface smoother; the image displaying these will be updated when the new mold is ready!

 -- the TGRI Containers body measures 4.47 inches (4.9" total.)

================================

 

What will the funds be used for?


Laboratory / Studio

As things stand my studio space is about 9x12 ft and is packed, leaving just enough room to walk! This project is intended to assist in the acquisition of a larger space to work in along with!


Vehicle

My car died a week ago, making it hard to get to and from. I need a vehicle that will allow me to get to and from work, along with going to set up at conventions to bring more enjoyable products to everyone!


Hardware:

I previously tried making items and having them printed by a third party, however on average each part takes fifteen days from order to reception. If something isn't right about the part (size, detail error, etc) it takes another fifteen days to get a new version- not to mention the extremely high cost of getting each print made. Prototyping this way makes it expensive and a very slow process. I have a PLA based printer and used it on the items available here, however it's level of detail is highly limited (I was pushing it with these items) and I need something more capable for the projects waiting in the wings! One hope of this fundraiser is to get enough funds to acquire the hardware I need to be able to produce everything myself.


Funding Goals: 

- Fallout Shelter
If I can get $2,000 I will be able to purchase a small storage building or shipping container to fix up and use as a studio!

- Escape Pod: $3,000
My car died last week; I need a good vehicle that will allow me the daily drive to work and to travel to set up at cons!
 

- Tools of Construction:  $3,300

--  A Formlabs Form 1 3D Printer is needed to allow me to prototype models and cast molds from them directly.This will allow high quality, high detailed models to be made on site without the three week delay or "layering" created by other 3d printers!


Any funds that are above the cost of the above will be used to acquire additional hardware to make creating art faster and better!

--  TabletPC with Wacom pen

-- Basic Jewelry Casting Equipment for Copper, Brass, Bronze and Silver

--  Low level Laser Engraver

 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Multiple Item Orders: The Pennies are Counters!
If you want more then one item, such as two or three Large Pocket Vials or a few GitD Necklaces, add the appropriate price per item noted in the items description!
The pennies ($0.01) are added to make it easier to know how many of an item is being ordered.
So, ($X.00) = one item, and ($X.04) equals first item plus four extras, for a total of five  items ordered. Having the price increase on the first item, then a reduced amount added for each additional is a simply way to ensure shipping is covered for each order but provide an easy way to allow multiple item to be ordered!

story:
The fundraising period has expired, but I'd still welcome your support.  For your contribution, I'm offering you the same rewards as listed on the right.  Thank you!




INTRO:
My name is Pan Trinity Das, and I've spent over a decade experimenting with a variety of different styles of art including: Abstract, figurative, landscape, psychedelic, portrait, mandala & yoga inspired artwork. Exploring mediums such as Painting, Tattoo, Silk Screening, Graffiti and Street Installation, Graphic Design, Carpentry, Sculpture, Photography and works in Industrial Metal.
 
After so many years of non-stop creation, a vision has a emerged, and with it a theme that merges my love of Bhakti (Devotional) Yoga with a style of art that I'm calling, “Spiritual Pop-Art.”

Messages in the Street uses a universal style of art to spread awareness about Consciousness, Yoga and the wisdom of the sages of India. My job as an artist is to represent the world I see and to tell a story that hasn't yet been told. Street art has long been a radical culture, often focused on societal repression, satire, and criticism. While I value these perspectives, I want to offer something positive and uplifting that speaks to the conscious revolution I see all around me.




3 ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT:
1. The artwork itself, which will leave a lasting impression.
2. Gathering as many people from the community to aid in the creation of the project, whereby we can directly and positively impact the landscape.
3. Telling the story with a series of short films so we can spread the art of conscious awareness around the globe.


GOAL:
*To honor the environment, and local & international revolutionary communities/organizations by offering mural services to aid in the promotion of worthy causes.
*To provide beautiful, uplifting, thought provoking, and evocative street messages that remind people that we are lucky to be alive is this time of tremendous change.
*To create commnunity through art.



"Jai Sri Ram"
(Hanumans Mantra)
Mural in Hampi, India 
*the Home of Hanuman
2012


SACRED STICKERS!

MERCHANDISE:
REMEMBER TO SPECIFY:
SIZE (S/M/L)
COLOR (Light Blue, White or Tri-Coffee)
IMAGE PREFERENCE (Gandhi, Amma Pray, Amma's Smile, Prabhupada, Buddha, Matarani or Neem Karoli Baba)

Over the last few months I've been developing my online store, which will be fully suppling this campaign with exclusive merchandise. You'll have access to never before seen Prints on Canvas, T-shirts, Printed Gift Cards, Hoodies and Stickers!!!

***PLEASE NOTE: Amma's Charitable organization will receive a donation for all merchandise purchased with her image!***

***To view CLICK HERE!***

AMMA t's


PROJECT UPDATES:

INDIA:
* I'm ecstatic to announce that I have been asked to continue my mural Seva (Selfless Service) for Amma's Ashram in Kerala. See Amma.org for more information about her and her Humanitarian Acts.

* I have been in contact with Jodie Underhill, the Founder of Waste Warriors, an organization responsible for installing Garbage and Recycling systems in Bhagsu, in Himal Pradesh. She was recently granted an audience with the secretary of the Dalai Lama who has since granted his blessing and support of the project. And personally speaking, Bhagsu is the cleanest place I've seen in ALL of India. I'm very excited to help spread their message to up India!

Waste Warriors:
https://www.facebook.com/wastewarriors0?fref=ts

NEPAL:
* I've recently made contact with a friend who volunteered last year painting a local school 20 minutes outside of Kathmandu. This school has expressed interested in receiving a mural of Lakshmi and I'm hoping to get the children involved so we can work on it together!

THAILAND:
* TBA

FRANCE:
* A journalist friend of mine works for an organization called "Street Art Paris." We did an interview for an article after the Beatles Cathedral Gallery Film premièred, she promised another article and to find me a wall if I ever decided to come to Paris. I'm so excited for my first trip to Europe!!

Maria Fernanda Hinke Scheichler:
http://mylifeonmybike.wordpress.com/

CANADA:
* TBA

USA:
*TBA

*** PLEASE NOTE: If you know of a charity, school, hospital, orphanage, ashram or not for profit organization that would be interested in receiving a mural in the above countries please let me know. If there's time I will do my best!


"MA MA MA"
(Sanskrit for Mother)
Mural in Arambol, India 
2012


WHERE YOUR $$$ WILL BE GOING:
Your money will be going directly to support the infrastructure of the project. Removing logistical concerns such as limited supplies needed to complete the installation in a given location. Each project will require 5-10 cans of Paint,  5-20 Brushes of varying sizes,  5-10 Markers, and a Measuring Tape. Printing costs are a constant expense and much time is spent on the internet researching new ideas and doing project updates. All of what you've seen in my short films has been shot almost entirely with my iPod Touch, and I'm really excited to see how much better we can tell the story with a camera upgrade. Depending on how much we're able to fundraise will determine what camera I can afford. On the lower end of the spectrum, I've been really impressed with the quality and the wide angle format of the infamous GoPro Camera. However, if funds allow I would love to step up to a more professional series camera and I've been very blown away with the performance of the Canon EOS 5D Mark II.



"Prabhupada"
Fine Art Print

"Let us focus on what we can give to others and not what we can take for ourselves. This will bring great transformation in our life." -Amma

story:
About PsyKandy: PsyKandy is a small business that I run by myself in Connecticut. My art mainly focuses on the use of crystals and minerals in resin, jewelry and other products.

The Goal: I would like to be able to make a larger quantity of orgone for my shop as well as to take more custom orders for those in need of my product. To me it is most enjoyable and important item that I create. And if you are asking yourself... what on Earth is orgone!? Well here is a brief summary! :)

Orgone is a life force energy that can be collected and stored in what is called an orgone generator. It dates back to the 1930s to a man named Wilhelm Reich who had created items such as orgone energy boxes for therapeutic use. Since then different forms, shapes and concepts of the science have been made. It is created from specific mixtures of organic and inorganic materials that create an energy field. Each generator is said to be helpful in turning negative energy into positive/balanced energy and to protect against the daily exposure to electromagnetic radiation/smog from cell phones, computers, television, etc.

Many people who have purchased an orgone generator from me have reported positive energy being felt from the objects. Some have said they use them for dream work, to help with sleeping at night, to help during meditation and yoga practices, to boost positivity, happiness and higher consciousness. With all of the electromagnetic smog and negativity we encounter everyday I feel that each person should have an orgone item on them, in their house, etc. at some point or another and I would like to be able to make more than I am currently so that everyone has a wider variety to choose from.

Each piece I create is done in multiple layers with various stones, metals, glitters, uv/glow materials, etc. I pour thin layers of resin into molds and spend a lot of time per layer making things as perfect as I can. Each layer sometimes takes up to 24 hours to fully dry and items I create generally range from 3-10+ layers which means each piece takes a few days before I can see the finished product.

For all of my orgone projects (and all other resin projects as well) I choose to use a top quality epoxy resin which is certainly pricey for the amount. Lower quality resin or different types of resin are a better deal for the money but sadly produce a toxic smell that is not good for my health or the health of others.

Here are some examples of orgone generators I create:

Pyramids and domes!

Orgone Jewelry! Necklaces, Rings, Plugs for stretched ears, etc.

Aside from everything else listed I create fun resin jewelry with stickers, glitter, candy, etc. and other types of crystal jewelry, pouches, dream catchers, etc. I also make hula hoops to be used for exercise and dance.

What will your pledges help with? I hope from this I can accomplish my goal in order to continue being able to create more unique orgone pieces and jewelry items. Since my item can be customized in almost anyway I would love to be able to create custom pieces more regularly to help people. All donations will go to materials such as resin, crystals, metals, etc. and any left over would go towards my other creations which would include jewelry findings, feathers and hoop materials. Also, I mainly sell my items online but have vended a few craft fairs and would love to do that more often as well as vend at holistic health fairs. Being able to create more items would help me fill the table space at these events. I started PsyKandy with high hopes from years of project designs that I wished would someday become items. I would love to keep my business moving up. This would help me immensely and all support is greatly appreciated.

Rewards: Most of the pledge points have multiple rewards to choose from. They will of course be created with the same quality as all the products I sell. Everyone who pledges will receive their gifts by Christmas.

story:
Kerfluffle!

There are some artists that just seem to easily find and retain venues for their work. I am not one of those artists. Most venues run away from me. I'm not yet sure if it's because I relentlessly pursue them until their entire staff is scared of me or I just have killer body odor. Either way the people at RAW: Natural Born Artists don't seem to mind and asked me to show at their April 30th exhibition in Raleigh, North Carolina. The problem is with all my stalkerish/perfectly normal behavior I realized that I don't have anything ready for a show let alone the funds to create something and transport it there. In that area I'm looking for help, hopefully your help. I'm an artist with a chance, please help me make it to RAW.

Thanks a bundle,

:D


How Everything Fits Together

$2500 is the magic number I am trying to come up with. In short the money will go to offsetting the show fees which include the venue, models, hair, make-up, marketing, meals, transportation and lodging. This will also help with the cost of materials and production for printing, matting, framing, and hanging the show. 


Why Me?

Whether it's a dollar or a hundred I consider every donation an investment. What does that investment mean?

  • Time Management - In a world where time equals money I don't want any of it to waste. Everything from the shoot dates and session times to the printing and assemblage time has been coordinated for simplicity and efficiency.
  • Quality - When I think of art I think of work that stands the test of time. So all of my works are printed,matted, and framed with image integrity and longevity in mind.
  • Confidence - As an artist I am not still in a place of self doubt. My series images convey individual stories without compromising the message of the series as a whole. I feel the uniqueness of my work combined with my attention to efficiency and quality is why my artwork is worth your investment.
  • When All Else Fails - Did you know that I am not only funny but quite adorable?


Other Ways You Can Help

For those of you who want to donate money but are unable to do so fear not! There are more than a few ways to help my cause.

  • Social Media - Sharing is caring. Tweet, Tumbl, Like and +1 this post 
  • Donation Station - If it can help me keep my costs down then send it my way
  • Word of Mouth - Tell people my story and ask them to share it. You never know who may be interested and want to help.

And that’s all there is to it. Thanks so much for everything!

story:
Click here to see how our campaign works or keep reading!

The Oxford Drunken Knitwits are making a calendar to raise money for Crisis Skylight Oxford, a charity that is dedicated to providing learning opportunities in the arts, music, literacy, and numeracy to people who are homeless or vulnerably housed in Oxford.

Knitting can make Oxford smile and raise money for Crisis at the same time! The calendar, called “We Knit Oxford”, will feature 12 photos of local Oxford knitters publicly displaying the joy and art of knitting. Each month, a photograph will display one or more knitters doing what they do best at quintessential Oxford monuments or locales, from the Headington Shark to Port Meadow, and everything in between, highlighting what makes our city so special.

We hope to be able to raise upwards of £13,500 through the sales of this calendar both online and in retail locations around Oxfordshire (book stores, wool shops, the Arts Café at the Old Fire Station, etc.).

In 2010, street and hidden homelessness began to rise. It is likely that homelessness will increase yet further as the delayed effects of the economic downturn, cuts to housing benefit and other reforms all start to bite. Crisis Skylight Oxford aims to lessen the suffering of homeless people in our city by providing learning opportunities which may boost employability and self-esteem.

Crisis Skylight Oxford always needs funds to help support their important work:

  • Workshops and activities like art, drama and yoga to engage homeless people and boost their self-esteem
  • High-quality training and education to prepare homeless people for work
  • CV-writing, interview skills, and education to help homeless people find jobs
  • Housing advice and access to decent permanent homes

While some of Crisis Skylight’s funding comes from grants and donated services and facilities, at least 60% of it must come from donations. 100% of our profits will go to Crisis Skylight Oxford. If there is enough interest in knitting workshops at their centre, we have asked Crisis Skylight to dedicate some of the proceeds specifically to offering these to the homeless of Oxford.

We need YOUR help to cover the printing costs of this calendar!

We plan to print 1,000 calendars, which will cost us around £1,500. Once these printing costs are covered, we can finish shooting photos for the remaining calendar months and get the files to the printer! The sale of these calendars, at £15 each, has the potential to raise over £13,500 for Crisis Skylight Oxford after the cost of printing and distribution.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute to our project at this time, there are still ways you can help!!

  • Share this page with your friends and family
  • Save money to purchase the calendar when it is available in retail stores in autumn
  • Volunteer your time or donate to Crisis Skylight Oxford!
